questions.text: A patient presents with severe pain and a throbbing swelling in the anal region. What type of incision will be used for incision and drainage in his management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cruciate incision:

  • A cruciate incision is the preferred method for incision and drainage of an abscess in the anal region. This technique involves making a cross-shaped incision, which allows for better drainage and prevents premature closure of the incision site.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are not the preferred incisions for anorectal abscess.

questions.text: Which of the following sets of nerves supply the muscles marked as A, B, C D in the image below?

choices.text: Axillary nerve, Lower subscapular nerve, and Dorsal scapular nerve
Upper subscapular nerve, and Axillary nerve
Accessory nerve, Thoracodorsal nerve, and Axillary Nerve

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Axillary nerve, Lower subscapular nerve, and dorsal scapular nerve:

  • The muscles marked in the image are the Teres major, Teres minor, and the rhomboids.
    • The Teres major is supplied by the lower subscapular nerve (C5, C6) and is responsible for adduction and medial rotation of the arm.
    • The Teres minor is supplied by the Axillary nerve (C5, C6) and is responsible for lateral rotation of the arm and holding the humeral head in the glenoid cavity.
    • The major and minor Rhomboids are supplied by the dorsal scapular nerve (C4, C5) and are responsible for retracting the scapula and rotating it to depress the glenoid cavity.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: The correct set of nerves and muscles has been mentioned in the explanation above.

questions.text: In disaster management, patients who need surgery within 24 hours are categorized under which color category of triage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Yellow:

  • Medium priority
  • Victims must be helped within 6 to 24 hours.
  • They can wait up to 24 hours.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Red:

  • High priority
  • Victims must be helped within 0 to 6 hours.

Option B - Green:

  • Low priority
  • These victims are ambulatory.
  • They can move with minor injuries.

Option D - Black:

  • Black: least priority

questions.text: Which of the following features is associated with MEN 4 Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neuroendocrine cervical cancer:

  • MEN 4 Syndrome, also known as MEN4A, is associated with neuroendocrine tumors, including those in the cervical region.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C:

  • Marfanoid habitus ,megacolon and medullated corneal nerve fibers are seen in MEN2B/3.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are most consistent with pulmonary fibrosis ?

choices.text: TLC and RV ↓ , FEV : FVC Increased,DLCO↓
TLC and RV↑,FEV : FVC Reduced, DLCO↓↓
TLC normal and RV ↑,FEV: FVC Reduced, DLCO ↓↓
TLC↓ and RV↑↑, FEV : FVC normal, DLCO↓

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - TLC and RV ↓ , FEV : FVC Increased, DLCO↓:

  • Pulmonary fibrosis will result in TLC and RV ↓ , FEV : FVC Increased, DLCO↓

Incorrect Options:

Option B - TLC and RV↑,FEV : FVC Reduced,DLCO↓↓ is seen in COPD

Option C - TLC normal and RV ↑,FEV: FVC Reduced, DLCO ↓↓ is seen in asthma

Option D - TLC↓ and RV↑↑,FEV: FVC normal, DLCO↓ is seen in Myasthenia gravis

questions.text: An enlarged diagram of the embryonic veins is shown below. The structure labeled ‘ A’ gives rise to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Internal Jugular Vein:

  • The structure marked ‘A’ in the above image is the anterior cardinal vein. This embryonic vein later develops into the internal jugular vein.

The following table summarises embryonic veins and their adult derivatives.

Embryonic

Adult

Vitelline vein

Right and left

Portion of the IVC, hepatic veins and sinusoids, ductus venosus, portal vein, inferior mesenteric vein, superior mesenteric vein, splenic vein

Umbilical veins

Right

Degenerative early in fetal life

Left

Ligamentum teres

Cardinal veins

Anterior

SVC, internal jugular veins

Posterior

Portion of IVC, common iliac veins

Subcardinal

Portion of IVC, renal veins, gonadal veins

Supracardinal

Portion of IVC, intercostal veins, hemiazygos vein, azygos vein

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Renal veins: These veins are derived from the subcardinal veins.

Option C - Intercostal veins: These veins are derived from the supracardinal veins.

Option D - Azygos vein: These veins are derived from the supracardinal veins.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the presence of IgG Anti GQ1b antibodies?

choices.text: Acute Motor and Sensory Axonal Neuropathy (AMSAN)

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Miller Fisher Syndrome:

  • This variant of GBS is identified by the triad of ophthalmoplegia, ataxia, and areflexia, and is associated with IgG anti-GQ1b antibodies.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are associated with IgG anti-GM1 antibodies not IgG Anti GQ1b

questions.text: A 32-year-old with a history of hepatitis B has been HBsAg positive for over six months, is HBeAg positive, and has IgG anti-HBc, high DNA polymerase, and elevated liver enzymes. What can be concluded about this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Supercarrier:

  • The patient has been positive for HBsAg for more than six months, positive HBeAg, a high viral load, and elevated liver enzymes (transaminases), which suggest that the patient is a supercarrier.

Incorrect Options:

Options A :Simple carriers will be negative for HBeAg

Option  C: Presence if IgM indicated recent infection, not IgG

Option  D: HBeAg positive indicates high infectivity not low

questions.text: An 18-month-old male baby is brought by his parents for routine vaccination. His previous vaccination is up to date. Which of the following vaccinations will not be given to this baby?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - PCV booster:

  • PCV booster is given at 9 completed months.
  • As the child is in 16-24 months PCV booster is not given.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - DPT booster: DPT booster is given at 16-24 months.

Option B - OPV booster: OPV booster is given at 16-24 months.

Option C - Japanese encephalitis 2nd dose: Japanese encephalitis 2nd dose is given at 16-24 months.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female para 2 presents with something coming out of her vagina. She says it started two months ago. She feels discomfort and back pain when she is standing for a long time in her kitchen, which is relieved by resting and lying down.On pelvic examination, there is uterocervical descent beyond the introitus. Which of the following is the most acceptable management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Fothergill's repair:

  • As the patient's age is 28 years, uterine preservation is a concern.
  • Uterine Preservation surgeries for prolapse are
    • Anterior and posterior pelvic repair
    • Fothergill's repair (Manchester surgery)
    • Shirodkar's procedure
    • Abdominal sling surgeries: Shirodkar, Khanna, Purandre's abdominocervicopexy.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Wertheim hysterectomy:

  • Wertheim hysterectomy is a radical abdominal hysterectomy used for the treatment of cervical cancer.

Option C - Perineal exercise x 3 months:

  • Perineal exercises can improve the symptoms to some extent, or atleast halt the progression of symptoms, but it is not the best management option.

Option D - Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair:

  • Vaginal hysterectomy with vault repair is a good management option in postmenopausal or old patients where uterus preservation is not a concern.

questions.text: Which of the following statements accurately describes the mechanism of action of methotrexate, an immunomodulator commonly used in rheumatoid arthritis?

choices.text: Methotrexate inhibits tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) to reduce inflammation and joint damage.
Methotrexate suppresses T-cell activation and proliferation by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase.
Methotrexate blocks interleukin-1 (IL-1) receptors to alleviate pain and swelling in affected joints.
Methotrexate enhances the activity of regulatory T cells (Tregs) to restore immune balance and prevent autoimmune reactions.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Methotrexate suppresses T-cell activation and proliferation by inhibiting dihydrofolate reductase:

  • Methotrexate is a folic acid analog that inhibits dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme involved in the synthesis of purines and pyrimidines necessary for DNA synthesis.
  • By inhibiting this enzyme, methotrexate interferes with the proliferation of rapidly dividing cells, including activated T cells, which play a key role in the pathogenesis of rheumatoid arthritis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Methotrexate inhibits tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α) to reduce inflammation and joint damage: This statement describes the mechanism of action of TNF-α inhibitors, such as adalimumab and etanercept, which directly target TNF-α to reduce inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B - Methotrexate blocks interleukin-1 (IL-1) receptors to alleviate pain and swelling in affected joints: This describes the mechanism of action of IL-1 inhibitors, such as anakinra, which block the activity of IL-1 receptors to reduce inflammation in rheumatoid arthritis.

Option D - Methotrexate enhances the activity of regulatory T cells (Tregs) to restore immune balance and prevent autoimmune reactions: While Tregs play a role in immune regulation, methotrexate does not directly enhance their activity. Its primary mechanism of action is through inhibition of T-cell activation and proliferation by targeting dihydrofolate reductase.

questions.text: A morbidly obese student presents with complaints of colored urine, pain, and dizziness with the slightest exercise and had to take multiple time offs to rest in between. Blood investigations revealed no hypoglycemia, normal bilirubin levels, normal lipid profile, and increased creatine kinase (CK) levels. Which of the following statements is incorrect concerning the suspected diagnosis?

choices.text: This condition is known to respond well to pyridoxine administration
There is exercise intolerance due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase
A liver biopsy was performed, revealing micronodular cirrhosis with marked intracytoplasmic glycogen deposits
The enzyme deficient in this condition is the rate-limiting enzyme for breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - A liver biopsy was performed, revealing micronodular cirrhosis with marked intracytoplasmic glycogen deposits:

  • The above-explained condition is suggestive of McArdle’s disease. It is defined as a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase and includes features like exercise intolerance without fasting, hypoglycemia, and hemolytic anemia.
  • A liver biopsy revealing micronodular cirrhosis with marked intracytoplasmic glycogen deposits is a marker of liver glycogen storage disorder, specifically a type IV GSD called Anderson Disease. It is characterized by the deficiency of the branching enzyme, normally encoded by the GBE1 gene(glycogen branching enzyme). McArdle’s disease does not have glycogen stored in hepatocytes but, instead, inside myocytes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - This condition is known to respond well to pyridoxine administration:

  • McArdle disease is indeed one of the few conditions that is known to improve by vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) administration. This is because vitamin B6 is one of the required coenzymes for glycogen phosphorylase.

Option B - There is exercise intolerance due to a deficiency of muscle glycogen phosphorylase:

  • Due to muscle glycogen phosphorylase deficiency, the stored glycogen inside myocyte cannot convert to glucose-1-phosphate to glucose-6-phosphate. Because of this, myocytes don't have available glucose molecules to enter glycolysis leading to exercise intolerance.

Option D - The enzyme deficient in this condition is the rate-limiting enzyme for breakdown of glycogen to glucose-1-phosphate:

  • The enzyme deficient in this condition, called the muscle glycogen phosphorylase is indeed the rate-limiting enzyme for the breakdown of glycogen.

questions.text: Which sign indicates pain in the right iliac fossa when pressing the left iliac fossa in a patient with acute appendicitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Rovsing's sign:

  • Rovsing's sign is seen in acute appendicitis. It can be elicited by pressing on the left side, which stretches the peritoneum and causes pain in the area of the inflamed appendix on the right side.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dunphy's sign: This sign refers to increased pain in the right lower quadrant when the patient coughs.

Option C - Psoas sign: This sign is seen when pain occurs in the right iliac fossa after hyperextension at the right hip joint.

Option D - Obturator sign: This sign is positive when pain on the internal rotation of the right thigh over the hip joint.

questions.text: A nurse sustains a needlestick injury while providing care to a known HIV-positive patient. Worried about potential exposure, what is the recommended laboratory investigation to assess the nurse's HIV status during the initial period after the incident, taking into consideration the potential window period?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - HIV-RNA:

  • HIV-RNA testing is recommended for early detection of HIV infection, as it directly detects the presence of the virus in the bloodstream. It is the first to rise in HIV infection.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:CD4 T-cell count will not decrease in the beginning of infection

Option B:HIV p24 antigen test is second to rise in HIV infection

Option D:Western blot test is the confirmatory test for HIV

questions.text: A chest X-ray (CXR) was performed on a Kota stone (marble) worker. Given his occupation, he is predisposed to which lung infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tuberculosis:

  • Workers exposed to silica dust, such as those working with Kota stone (marble), are at increased risk for developing silicosis, an occupational lung disease. Silicosis significantly increases the risk of developing pulmonary tuberculosis (TB).
  • The lung damage caused by silica dust makes individuals more susceptible to TB infection.
  • The characteristic finding on a CXR in TB is the "snowstorm" appearance, also known as a miliary pattern, which represents numerous small nodules spread throughout the lungs.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Aspergillosis:

  • Aspergillosis is a fungal infection caused by Aspergillus species. It is not specifically associated with occupational exposure to marble dust.

Option C - Pneumocystis pneumonia:

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP) caused by the fungus Pneumocystis jiroveci predominantly affects individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS, cancer. It is not commonly associated with occupational exposures like those encountered by marble workers.

Option D - Silicosis:

  • Silicosis itself is not an infection but a chronic lung disease caused by inhaling silica dust. It leads to inflammation and scarring of the lungs. While silicosis predisposes individuals to other infections, particularly tuberculosis, it is not an infection alone. On a CXR, silicosis can show a ground-glass appearance with thickened intralobular and interlobular septa called crazy paving.

questions.text: According to the Forrest Classification of upper GI bleeds, which type has an intermediate risk of re-bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IIB:

  • In the Forrest Classification of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeds, Type IIB has an intermediate risk of re-bleeding.

Incorrect Options:

Option A and B: Type IB and IIA are associated with a high risk of re-bleeding.

Option D - III: Type III ulcers are associated with a low risk of re-bleeding.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician with a history of persistent inspiratory stridor. The stridor is more prominent when the baby is lying on their back but improves when in the prone position. Additionally, the parents notice an increase in the stridor when the baby cries. What is the management of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Epiglottopexy:

  • The described clinical presentation points towards the diagnosis of Laryngomalacia. Epiglottopexy is the preferred surgical management of laryngomalacia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Balloon dilation: It is performed in cases of subglottic stenosis. Subglottic stenosis does not affect inspiration and expiration and does not affect crying.

Option B - Laser vaporization: It is performed in cases of subglottic hemangioma, in which there will be no inspiratory and expiratory stridor. If present, a biphasic stridor is present.

Option C - Intralesional steroids: It is used in management in cases of laryngeal web. The patient of laryngeal web presents with biphasic stridor which increases on crying. However, in this case, stridor is only present with inspiration.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is commonly used as first-line therapy for chronic gout by lowering serum uric acid levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Allopurinol:

  • Allopurinol is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that is commonly used as first-line therapy for chronic gout.
  • It works by inhibiting the enzyme xanthine oxidase, thereby reducing the production of uric acid.
  • By lowering serum uric acid levels, allopurinol helps prevent the formation of urate crystals and subsequent gout flares.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Probenecid: Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes renal excretion of uric acid. While it can be used for gout management, it is typically reserved for patients who cannot tolerate or have contraindications to allopurinol.

Option C - Colchicine: Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that is used for the treatment of acute gout flares. It does not lower serum uric acid levels and is not used for chronic management of gout.

Option D - Prednisone: Prednisone is a corticosteroid that can be used to reduce inflammation and relieve symptoms during acute gout flares. It is not used for chronic management of gout or for lowering serum uric acid levels.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with complaints of a fishy odor and an increase in vaginal discharge over the past week. She notes that the discharge is thin, grayish-white, and more noticeable after sexual intercourse. She denies any itching or burning sensation. Which of the following is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Metronidazole is given as treatment only to the female

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Colpitis Macularis:

The above given scenario is suggestive of bacterial vaginosis

  • Colpitis macularis is a term that is not specifically associated with bacterial vaginosis.
  • The term "colpitis" generally refers to inflammation of the vaginal lining also known as the Strawberry Vagina. Seen in Trichomoniasis

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D are true regarding bacterial vaginosis.

questions.text: Which of the following should be checked for spontaneous return of circulation in infants during resuscitation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Brachial Pulse:

  • The brachial artery is located in the antecubital fossa.
  • In infants, the brachial pulse is checked for return of spontaneous circulation during resuscitation.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B:

  • Guidelines diﬀer for infants and pediatric age groups in assessing circulation.
  • In infants, the brachial pulse is checked for return of spontaneous circulation
  • In pediatric and adult patients, the carotid or femoral pulse is examined.

Option C - Radial pulse:

  • Checking the radial pulse is a common method of assessing the pulse in adults and older children.
  • The radial artery is located on the thumb side of the wrist, and it is easily accessible for pulse assessment.
  • However, it is not assessed for checking the return for spontaneous circulation in infants during resuscitation.

questions.text: Which component of the bacterial cell wall is absent in the cell wall of the gram-positive bacterium?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Lipopolysaccharides (LPS):

  • Lipopolysaccharides are mainly found in the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria. Lipopolysaccharides are not present in the cell walls of gram-positive bacteria.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are present in the cell wall of the gram-positive bacterium.

questions.text: Which of the following causes Hyperkalemic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Options - Gordon syndrome:

  • Gordon syndrome, also known as pseudohypoaldosteronism type II or familial hyperkalemic hypertension, is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hypertension presenting from childhood, hyperkalemia from birth, and metabolic acidosis.
  • Patients usually have suppressed PRA and normal aldosterone.
  • It is caused by mutations affecting the thiazide-sensitive sodium-chloride cotransporter (NCC) in the distal convoluted tubule, leading to sodium and potassium retention as well as metabolic acidosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Renal tubular acidosis type 1: Renal tubular acidosis type 1 typically presents with hypokalemic acidosis due to impaired renal acidification of urine. This condition is characterized by decreased hydrogen ion secretion in the distal tubule, leading to acidosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect in the context of hyperkalemic acidosis.

Option B - Cushing syndrome: Cushing syndrome, caused by prolonged exposure to high levels of cortisol, can lead to hyperkalemia due to its effects on promoting potassium retention by the kidneys. However, it usually results in metabolic alkalosis rather than acidosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

Option C - Liddle syndrome: Liddle syndrome is a rare genetic disorder characterized by hypertension and hypokalemia, typically due to increased activity of the epithelial sodium channel (ENaC) in the distal nephron. This increased sodium reabsorption is usually associated with metabolic alkalosis rather than acidosis. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: Which type of laceration is depicted in the provided image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Split laceration:

  • The given image shows a split laceration. The wound has clean-cut and regular margins.
  • It typically involves the tearing of tissues along the line of the wound.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Cut laceration: A cut laceration is a result of a sharp object or instrument cutting through the skin and underlying tissues. It is a common type of laceration and can vary in depth and length.

Option C - Stretch laceration: A stretch laceration occurs when tissues are forcibly stretched beyond their normal capacity, resulting in tearing and the formation of a flap, as seen in this image. This type of injury is often associated with rapid and forceful stretching, leading to a distinct pattern of tissue damage.

Option D - Grinding laceration: A grinding laceration is caused by friction or abrasion against a rough surface. This type of injury often involves a combination of tearing and abrasion, and it can result in a unique pattern of tissue damage.

questions.text: Identify the device given in the image:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ring Adair Elwyn's tube:

  • The RAE tube is also known as the "south pole tube" (universal connector facing towards the lower part of the patient) or the "north pole tube" (universal connector facing towards the head of the patient), depending on the bend of the tube.
  • These are easy to secure and keep the breathing circuit away from the surgical ﬁeld.
  • They are used for oro-maxillofacial surgery.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Flexometallic tube:

  • These have metallic wiring inside, which makes them kink-resistant.
  • These are used in the prone position for neurosurgery and spine surgery. A normal PCV tube can get compressed, leading to obstruction of oxygen or inhalational agents. This is prevented by the flexometallic tube.

Option C - Double lumen tube:

  • A double-lumen tube is a modification of an infraglottic device.
  • It has two lumens, the tracheal and bronchial lumens.

Option D - Nasopharyngeal device:

  • These are used only to provide a little oxygen to the patient or a support system to the supraglottic and infraglottic airway devices.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the eye clinic with complaints of redness, itching, and ropy discharge. He mentions that these symptoms worsen during the summer months. On examination, the doctor notices the presence of a pseudomembrane on the papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva. What is the term used to describe this characteristic appearance?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Maxwell Lyon’s sign:

  • The clinical picture of a male child along with ropy discharge which exacerbates in summer gives the diagnosis of vernal keratoconjunctivitis, and the finding described in the question and image is called Maxwell Lyon’s sign. It is a pseudomembrane formed due to excessive deposition of mucus on the papilla.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Cobblestone appearance: Cobblestone appearance is seen in the palpebral form of vernal conjunctivitis where papillary reaction leads to the formation of giant papillae on the upper tarsal conjunctiva.

Option B - Horner trantas spots: Horner trantas spots are seen in the limbal form of vernal conjunctivitis these are white dots containing eosinophils on the limbal area.

Option C - Pseudogerontoxon: Pseudogerontoxon is also seen in the limbal form of vernal conjunctivitis, where the cornea is involved, and there is a formation of cupid’s bow, it is a lesion that resembles a small segment of arcus senilis hence called pseudogerontoxon.

questions.text: Which of the following is the true definition of still birth rate?

choices.text: Death of a fetus weighing at least 1000 grams, equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation per 1000 total births
Death of a fetus weighing at least 1200 grams, equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation per 1000 total births
Death of a fetus weighing at least 1000 grams, equivalent to 20 weeks of gestation per 1000 total births
Early neonatal death (0-7 days) weighing at least 1200 grams per 1000 total births

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Death of a fetus weighing at least 1000 grams equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation per 1000 total births:

  • Stillbirth is the Death of a fetus weighing at least 1000 grams, equivalent to 28 weeks of gestation per 1000 total births.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options B, C, and D are incorrect, as given above.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement:

choices.text: Danger abscess is a subtype of prevertebral abscess that ends at the level of T4 vertebrae
Prevertebral abscess appears on the side of the midline, and retropharyngeal abscess appears on the midline
Prevertebral space is a paired space, whereas retropharyngeal space is a single space
Prevertebral and retropharyngeal abscesses begin at the base of the skull.

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Prevertebral and retropharyngeal abscesses begin at the base of the skull:

  • Both prevertebral and retropharyngeal abscesses originate at the base of the skull. Prevertebral abscesses extend inferiorly to the coccyx, while retropharyngeal abscesses can extend inferiorly to different levels depending on whether they are true compartment abscesses or danger space abscesses.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Danger abscess is a subtype of prevertebral abscess that ends at the level of T4 vertebrae:

  • Danger space abscesses associated with retropharyngeal abscesses may extend to the level of the diaphragm, not T4 vertebrae.

Option B - Prevertebral abscess appears on the side of the midline, and retropharyngeal abscess appears on the midline:

  • Retropharyngeal abscesses appear on the side of the midline due to the paired retropharyngeal space, while prevertebral abscesses present as a midline bulge.

Option C - Prevertebral space is a paired space, whereas retropharyngeal space is a single space:

  • The retropharyngeal space is paired, and the prevertebral space is a single space.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the dermatology outpatient department with complaints of patchy hair loss. Examination reveals the findings shown in the image below. A closer examination of the hair towards its margins reveals an ‘exclamation mark’ pattern. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: This type of hair loss is associated with scarring
The underlying mechanism is suspected to be a T cell-mediated autoimmune process
This type of hair loss only affects the scalp
Topical minoxidil is the first-line treatment for this condition

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - The underlying mechanism is suspected to be a T cell-mediated autoimmune process:

  • The likely diagnosis for this patient is alopecia areata. The characteristic lesion in this disease is a well-circumscribed, smooth, hairless patch, and the skin within this patch usually appears normal or slightly erythematous.
  • Closer examination of the hair towards the margin in these patients demonstrates an ‘exclamation mark’ pattern. Alopecia areata causes nonscarring hair loss that is suspected to be due to an autoimmune T-cell-mediated process.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - This type of hair loss is associated with scarring:

  • Alopecia areata is a type of non-cicatricial alopecia.

Option C - This type of hair loss only affects the scalp:

  • Alopecia areata can involve any hair-growing skin (for example - beard) though it more commonly affects the scalp.

Option D - Topical minoxidil is the first-line treatment for this condition:

  • The first-line treatment for this condition is a potent topical corticosteroid such as clobetasol. Intralesional depot steroids (Hydrocortisone 25 mg/mL or Triamcinolone acetonide 5-10 mg/ml) have also been found to be effective in stimulating hair growth.

questions.text:
Observe the images and select the correct option that states the proper order of sample disposal into the tubes.

			2.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			3.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 4,2,1,3:

Following a standardized order of draw reduces the risk of contamination between tubes and ensures that additives do not interfere with subsequent tests.

4. Blue vacutainer:

  • Anticoagulant used- Trisodium Citrate.

2. Green vacutainer:

  • Anticoagulant used - Heparin.

1. Purple vacutainer:

  • Anticoagulant used- K2EDTA.
  • Used for CBC, Peripheral smear, HbA1C, etc.

3. Grey vacutainer:

  • Anticoagulant used- K Oxalate, Additive- NaF.
  • Used for Glucose estimation studies.
  • Ideally to be filled after all the given containers.

 

Incorrect Options: 

  • Option A, B and D are incorrect.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy presents with cola-colored urine and pedal edema and gives a history of sore throat 2 weeks back which was not treated with antibiotics. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient's condition?

1. It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.

2. Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12 and 4 are responsible.

3. Gross findings on the kidney shows a flea-bitten appearance.

4. Linear immunofluorescence is seen.
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 1, 2 and 3 are true:

  • The clinical presentation and history of sore throat is suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • The correct statements are:
    • It is a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction (Immune complex-mediated)
    • Streptococcus pyogenes: strains 12 and 4 are responsible.
    • Gross findings on the kidney show a flea-bitten appearance.
  • Liner immunofluorescence is seen in good pasture syndrome. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis shows a starry sky immunofluorescence.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy was brought by his parents with severe pain in his limbs. His mother also complained of a typical smell from his urine and compared it to the odor of cabbage. On examination, the boy appeared icteric. USG of the abdomen revealed liver cirrhosis. Renal function tests also revealed elevated creatine levels. What is the possible diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tyrosinemia type 1:

  • The above symptoms of pain in the limbs along with a cabbage odor, liver cirrhosis, and renal impairment point to the possibility of type 1 Tyrosinemia, aka, hepatorenal syndrome. These patients are known to experience acute bouts of severe pain due to peripheral neuropathy.
  • It occurs due to a deficiency of the enzyme Fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase.
  • As a result of the deficiency, fumarylacetoacetate (precursor) accumulates in the parenchymal cells of the liver and kidney and exerts toxic effects (Fanconi syndrome progresses to renal failure).
  • This results in jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, liver cirrhosis, and renal failure.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Tyrosinemia type 2: Tyrosinemia type 2 is also called oculo-cutaneous syndrome. It is characterized by painful corneal erosions and palmar hyperkeratosis. It occurs due to a deficiency of tyrosine transaminase.

Option C - Tyrosinemia type 3: Tyrosinemia type 3 presents with recurrent seizures and intermittent ataxia. It can be characterized by hawkinsuria, which is a swimming pool odor of urine. It occurs due to a deficiency of P-hydroxy phenylpyruvate dioxygenase

Option D - Alkaptonuria:

  • Alkaptonuria occurs due to a deficiency of homogentisate oxidase. Homogentisic acid accumulates in the blood and undergoes oxidation to form benzoquinone acetate. It polymerizes to form melanin-like fibers, leading to pigmentation of the skin and mucous membrane.
  • Symptoms include multiple joint involvements, multiple intervertebral disc bulges, and knee pain. Urine characteristically turns dark on standing.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the measuring instrument /device given below?

choices.text: It is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of Air
It does not record air velocity
It is used to measure corrected eﬀective temperature
It is used to measure Air humidity

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of Air:

  • The given image is of a kata thermometer.
  • In the Kata thermometer, dry Kata reading is more than 6 and wet Kata reading is more than 20 - indicates thermal comfort.
  • It is used to measure low air velocity and cooling power of Air

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It does not record air velocity: It is used to record air velocity.

Option C - It is used to measure corrected eﬀective temperature: Globe thermometer is used to measure corrected eﬀective temperature or radiant heat not kata thermometer.

Option D - It is used to measure Air humidity: It is used to measure Air humidity. This is a wrong statement as kata thermometer measures air quality.

questions.text:
Match the following precipitation reactions with their respective diffusion and dimension:


	
		
			
			1. Oudin test
			
			
			a. Double diffusion in two-dimension
			
		
		
			
			2. Oakley Fulthorpe Test
			
			
			b. Single diffusion in one-dimension
			
		
		
			
			3. Radial Immunodiffusion
			
			
			c. Single diffusion in two-dimension
			
		
		
			
			4. Ouchterlony Test
			
			
			d. Double diffusion in one-dimension
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1-b, 2-d, 3-c, 4-a:

  • Oudin Test: In the Oudin test, antigens diffuse into a column of gel-containing antibodies, leading to precipitation bands. This involves single diffusion in one dimension, where the antigen moves in one direction through the gel.
  • Oakley Fulthorpe Test: This test involves the migration of both antigens and antibodies towards each other in a gel but in a one-dimensional space, leading to the formation of precipitation lines.
  • Radial Immunodiffusion: In radial immunodiffusion, antigens diffuse radially from a well into a gel containing uniformly distributed antibodies, forming a circular precipitate. This involves single diffusion in a two-dimensional plane.
  • Ouchterlony Test: The Ouchterlony test involves the diffusion of both antigens and antibodies in a two-dimensional plane within a gel, leading to lines of precipitation where they meet.

questions.text: All of the following will cause activation of the Bezold-Jarisch reflex except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Hypervolemic state:

  • In a hypervolemic state, the Bainbridge reflex is always dominant over the baroreceptor, and the heart rate will increase.
  • It does not activate Bezold-Jarisch reflex

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C will activate Bezold-Jarisch reflex

questions.text: The highest sensitivity for detecting pulmonary embolism is given by ?
questions.solution:
Correct C - Doppler study:

  • Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) has the highest sensitivity for detecting air in the right ventricular outflow tract or major pulmonary veins, capable of identifying as little as 0.02 mL/kg of air.
  • Doppler ultrasonography provides audible detection of venous air embolism and identifies paradoxical air embolism (PAE).
  • Doppler ultrasonography estimates blood flow through vessels by bouncing high-frequency sound waves off circulating red blood cells..
  • Overall highest sensitivity : T.E.E > Doppler > E.T N2> E.T CO2

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect as given above.

  • In the case of air embolism, the primary investigation of choice is transesophageal echocardiography and a Doppler study.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with increased TSH with high unbound T4?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Thyroid hormone resistance:

  • Thyroid hormone resistance syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by reduced responsiveness of target tissues to thyroid hormones.
  • In this condition, despite elevated TSH levels (due to decreased negative feedback), the tissues do not adequately respond to thyroid hormones, leading to high unbound T4 levels.
  • Therefore, thyroid hormone resistance is a plausible cause of increased TSH with high unbound T4.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pituitary apoplexy:

  • Pituitary apoplexy typically presents with a sudden severe headache, visual disturbances, and hypopituitarism due to hemorrhage or infarction of the pituitary gland. In this condition, TSH secretion is usually impaired due to pituitary gland dysfunction, resulting in low TSH levels. Therefore, pituitary apoplexy is unlikely to cause increased TSH with high unbound T4.

Option C and D - Primary thyrotoxicosis and Toxic multinodular goiter:

  • Primary thyrotoxicosis and Toxic multinodular goiter will present with low TSH and high unbound T4.

questions.text:
A Hepatitis B patient with liver cirrhosis develops massive ascites and shortness of breath. He is on spironolactone in addition to furosemide. An arterial blood gas (ABG) report shows the following values:


	pH = 7.55
	PCO₂ = 38 mm Hg
	HCO₃⁻ = 33 meq/L
	Na = 140 mEq/L
	Chloride = 91 mEq/L
	Anion Gap (AG) = 16 mEq/L


Based on the ABG report and clinical context, what is the most likely acid-base disorder in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory alkalosis:

  • The patient's ABG values indicate an alkalotic state (pH = 7.55). The elevated HCO₃⁻ (33 meq/L) confirms metabolic alkalosis.
  • The expected compensatory PCO₂ for metabolic alkalosis would be higher (HCO₃⁻ + 15 = 33 + 15 = 48 mm Hg).
  • The actual PCO₂ is lower at 38 mm Hg, indicating a concurrent respiratory alkalosis.
  • This mixed disorder is likely due to the combined effects of diuretic use (causing metabolic alkalosis) and the patient’s shortness of breath leading to hyperventilation (causing respiratory alkalosis).

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Metabolic alkalosis with respiratory acidosis:

  • The patient's ABG shows an elevated pH,indicating alkalosis. Metabolic alkalosis is supported by an elevated HCO₃⁻ of 33 meq/L. However, respiratory acidosis would be characterized by an elevated PCO₂, not a normal value of 38 mm Hg.

Option C - High anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • The patient’s anion gap is 16 mEq/L, which is within the upper limit of the normal range. High anion gap metabolic acidosis would present with a decreased pH (acidosis), not an increased pH. The patient’s pH is 7.55, indicating alkalosis, not acidosis.

Option D - Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis:

  • Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis is characterized by a normal anion gap and a decrease in pH (acidosis). This patient's pH is elevated, indicating alkalosis, not acidosis. Furthermore, the bicarbonate level is elevated, which is inconsistent with metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old alcoholic patient presents to the emergency department with a complaint of palpitations, chest discomfort, and syncope. His PR is 240bpm, BP: 85/60mmHg. I/V esmolol has been given to this patient for rate control. Which of the following should be given next for rhythm control?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IV Ibutilide:

  • The above ECG and symptoms are suggestive of atrial fibrillation
  • As Esmolol has already been administered for rate control, IV Ibutilide should be given for rhythm control

Treatment: R.A.C.E

  • Rate control: I.V Esmolol/ Verapamil
    • Anticoagulation: 1° pulmonary embolism
  • Rhythm Control:
    • Chemical cardioversion- I.V Amiodarone/ Ibutilide(preferred first)
    • Electrical cardioversion: DC shock of 25- 50J biphasic

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV Verapamil:

  • Verapamil is given for rate control but as esmolol has been administered already. there is no requirement of verapamil

Option B – Rivoroxabin:

  • NO need for anticoagulants in recent onset of atrial ﬁbrillation.
  • Need for anticoagulants in atrial ﬁbrillation decided by
    • Transesophageal echocardiography
    • CHA2D S2 VA Sc

Option D - IV Amiodarone:

  • Although IV amiodarone can also be given for rhythm control, IV Ibutilide is the preferred drug in atrial fibrillation

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the Framingham minor criteria?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Bilateral crepts:

  • Bilateral crepts are included in the major criteria not minor criteria

Incorrect Options:

Option A,B and C:

  • Oliguria, pitting edema , and pleural effusion are included in the Framingham minor criteria

questions.text: Which of the following diseases follow the Iceberg phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Tuberculosis:

  • Tuberculosis is one of the diseases that follow the iceberg phenomenon
  • Diseases that follow the Iceberg phenomenon are
    • Non-communicable diseases.
    • Cancer.
    • Protein-energy malnutrition cases.
    • Tuberculosis.
    • HIV

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and C are incorrect as they are included in the disease that donot follow the Iceberg phenomenon
  • Diseases that don't follow the Iceberg phenomenon are.
    • Measles.
    • Rabies (highest CFR rate).
    • Tetanus.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman lives alone in a modest house. Over the past few years, her neighbors have noticed a gradual accumulation of items in and around her home that most people would consider unnecessary. Which of the following is exhibited by this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hoarding Disorder:

  • In this scenario, the old women exhibits key features of Hoarding Disorder, characterized by persistent difficulty discarding or parting with possessions, regardless of their actual value.
  • The accumulation of possessions leads to living spaces becoming cluttered and crowded, causing significant distress and impairment in daily functioning.
  • Individuals with Hoarding Disorder often have strong emotional attachments to their possessions and may experience anxiety or distress at the thought of discarding them. Treatment typically involves a combination of therapy, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), and SSRI.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Social Anxiety Disorder:

  • Social Anxiety Disorder: Some individuals with social anxiety may avoid discarding items due to fears of judgment or scrutiny by others.
  • However, in Hoarding Disorder, the primary difficulty lies in parting with possessions, even when alone, and not solely driven by social fears.

Option B - Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder:

  • Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD): Individuals with OCD may engage in compulsive behaviors, including hoarding.
  • However, in OCD, hoarding is just one of many compulsive behaviors, and the obsessions (intrusive thoughts) driving the behavior are typically different from the strong attachment to possessions seen in Hoarding Disorder.

Option D - Kleptomania:

  • Individuals with kleptomania have an irresistible urge to steal items, even though they may not have any use for or intention to keep the stolen items.
  • The theft is impulsive, and unplanned, and is often followed by a sense of relief or gratification.
  • Whereas individuals with hoarding disorder experience persistent difficulty parting with possessions, leading to an excessive accumulation of items.
  • Hoarding is characterized by an intense emotional attachment to possessions, a fear of discarding items, and the belief that these items have value or utility.

questions.text: Based on the CT scan image, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Intraventricular hemorrhage:

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Intraparenchymal Hemorrhage

  • The above NCCT shows a hyperdense pathology (acute hemorrhage within the parenchyma).
  • It is known as the intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
  • The hemorrhage is present in the basal ganglia (Internal capsule) area.

Option B - ACOM aneurysm:

  • Aneurysm with the calcified wall
  • Acom aneurysm can compress the optic chiasma.

Option C - Subarachnoid hemorrhage:

  • The blood appears white on non-contrast CT (subarachnoid hemorrhage)
  • It has a Pentagon shape or star shape.
  • It is also called the Star of Death.

questions.text: Which of the following serotypes of HPV is most malignant?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - HPV-18: 

  • HPV-18 is more specific than HPV-16 for invasive tumors that implies, HPV-18 is the most malignant.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HPV-6: HPV-6 is considered a low-risk type and is commonly associated with genital warts (condyloma acuminata) and benign lesions.

Option B - HPV-16: HPV-16 is a high-risk type and is the most common serotype associated with cervical carcinoma. It is considered one of the major causative agents of cervical cancer.

Option C - HPV 11: Similar to HPV-6, HPV-11 is a low-risk type and is often associated with genital warts and benign lesions. These types are not strongly linked to cervical cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical compound is present in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Nonoxynol-9:

  • Nonoxynol-9 is a chemical compound commonly used in vaginal sponges and some contraceptive products. It belongs to the class of nonionic surfactants and is known for its spermicidal properties. Nonoxynol-9 works by disrupting the sperm cell membrane, thereby preventing fertilization. It is used as a contraceptive method, particularly in barrier methods such as vaginal sponges.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Menfegol: Explanation: Menfegol is not commonly used in vaginal sponges. It is a spermicide that has been used in some contraceptive formulations.

Option C - Benzalkonium Chloride: Benzalkonium chloride is not a typical component of vaginal sponges. It is a quaternary ammonium compound with antiseptic properties and is commonly found in some disinfectants and topical antiseptic solutions.

Option D4 - Nitrile: Nitrile is not a chemical used in vaginal sponges for contraceptive purposes. Nitrile is a type of synthetic rubber used in various products, including gloves and condoms. It is a type of material not a chemical.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors primarily detect Tactile acuity?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Merkel's Disc:

  • Merkel's Disc is the best receptor for detecting two-point discrimination, also known as Tactile acuity. If the receptor's receptive field is smaller, it will be best for detecting two points separately.
  • Tactile acuity is best in the case of females and is found at the tip of the finger.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Ruffini's ending:

  • It best detects the size and shape of hand-held objects

Option C - Free Nerve Ending:

  • The best stimulus is itching and tickling kind of sensations.

Option D – Meissner's Corpuscles:

  • Most numerous touch receptors in our body.
  • The best stimulus is moving touch.
  • Also, the stimulus for vibration detection with a frequency lower than 50 Hz.
  • Located only in non-hairy skin, also known as Glabrous skin

questions.text: What is the most common site where a thyroglossal cyst occurs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Subhyoid region:

  • Subhyoid region is the most common site of occurrence for a thyroglossal cyst. Most thyroglossal cysts are found in this region because the duct tract commonly persists here during embryonic development.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are not the most common sites of a thyroglossal cyst.

questions.text: A middle-aged patient with a longstanding history of alcohol abuse is brought to the outpatient department by his caretakers for the evaluation of a rash. The patient appears confused and is unable to take care of himself. He is wearing adult diapers that are changed multiple times a day due to frequent watery bowel movements. Examination of the patient reveals a rash, as shown in the image below. Which of the following nutrient deficiencies is responsible for this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Vitamin B3:

  • Vitamin B3 (Niacin) is a water-soluble vitamin, and deficiency of this vitamin leads to Pellagra.
  • Niacin deficiency is common in countries with high grain and low meat consumption, such as India. This deficiency is exacerbated in patients with chronic alcoholism and eating disorders.
  • Pellagra is characterized by the following symptoms:
    • Dermatitis
    • Diarrhea
    • Dementia
    • If untreated, Death

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D: These deficiencies are not associated with Pellagra.

questions.text: A 42-year-old nulliparous woman presents with a lump in her left breast for three months. The lump enlarges before her menstrual cycle and reduces in size afterward. A single, non-tender, firm lump measuring 2 cm with well-defined soft margins in the upper outer quadrant of her left breast is observed on examination. What are the findings likely to be seen on this patient's mammogram?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Popcorn calcification:

  • The given clinical findings are suggestive of a fibroadenoma, a common benign breast tumor often influenced by hormonal changes. The hallmark mammographic feature of a fibroadenoma is the presence of popcorn calcifications.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not seen in fibroadenoma

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the pediatric emergency department complaining of a persistent barking cough. On examination, the child is in respiratory distress. A plain radiograph of the chest shows the following finding. Which of the following is not a part of the recommended initial treatment options for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - IV Ceftriaxone:

  • The likely diagnosis in this child is acute laryngotracheobronchitis (Croup) and antibiotics are not indicated in managing this condition.
  • Croup is a viral upper respiratory tract infection commonly seen in children between 6 months to 3 years of age.
  • The most common causative organism is the parainfluenza virus.
  • There is initially a viral prodrome in which patients present with a barking cough, biphasic stridor, and low-grade fever. A plain radiograph reveals a characteristic narrowing of the subglottic region (Steeple sign) in severe cases.

 

 

 

Most patients with croup have a mild illness that resolves within 1-2 days with conservative management.

Usually, these patients are managed with the following:

  • Supportive care
  • Oxygen therapy
  • Single dose dexamethasone - Oral/IM
  • In severe cases, nebulised epinephrine along with corticosteroids may be used.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are recommended treatment strategies for managing patients with croup.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of lethargy, easy fatiguability, recurrent infections, and spontaneous gum bleeding . Physical examination reveals massive hepatosplenomegaly. The bone marrow cytology findings are shown below. The child’s presentation is due to the accumulation of which toxic metabolite?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Glucocerebroside:

  • The diagnosis in this child is Gaucher’s disease
  • Gaucher’s disease is an autosomal recessively inherited lysosomal storage disorder.
  • It occurs due to a deficiency of glucocerebrosidase.
  • This enzyme is responsible for removing glucose from glucosylceramide.
  • Bone marrow cytology with a Gaucher cell demonstrating the crumpled paper appearance.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - GM1 Ganglioside:

  • GM1 ganglioside accumulation is seen in patients with beta-galactosidase deficiency. The resulting disease is called GM1 gangliosidosis. Patients can present with hepatosplenomegaly and bone pain but bone marrow cytology showing a ‘crumpled paper’ appearance is suggestive of Gaucher’s disease.

Option C - Uric acid:

  • Uric acid accumulation is seen in patients with HGPRT enzyme deficiency. The resulting disorder is known as Lesch Nyhan syndrome. Self-mutilation is a characteristic feature.

Option D - Sulfated glycosphingolipids:

  • Elevated levels of sulfated glycosphingolipids in the white matter is seen in patients with metachromatic leukodystrophy. This disorder is characterised by rapid deterioration of nervous system functions in the second year of life.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones act on the Cytokine receptor, causing the direct phosphorylation of the Intracellular protein and activating the JAK-STAT pathway?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Prolactin:

  • Prolactin is a hormone that acts on cytokine receptors, leading to the direct phosphorylation of intracellular proteins and activating the JAK-STAT pathway. Prolactin receptors are associated with Janus kinase (JAK) activation and subsequent activation of signal transducer and activator of transcription (STAT) proteins, initiating the JAK-STAT signaling cascade.

Incorrect Options:

Option A and B - Insulin and IGF-1:

  • Phosphorylate proteins like AKT and MAP kinase pathway.

Option C - Epithelial growth factor:

  • Phosphorylate proteins like Ras, Raf, and MAP kinase pathway.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old male patient with hypertension and type 2 diabetes is prescribed a new oral medication for his condition. The medication is known to undergo extensive first-pass metabolism in the liver. Despite being compliant with the medication, the patient reports minimal improvement in his blood pressure control after one month. The physician suspects that the bioavailability of the drug might be contributing to the suboptimal therapeutic effect.

Which of the following factors is most likely affecting the bioavailability of the drug in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Extensive first-pass metabolism:

  • This is the most likely factor affecting the bioavailability of the drug in this patient.
  • First-pass metabolism refers to the process by which a drug is metabolized in the liver immediately after being absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract and before it reaches the systemic circulation.
  • Extensive first-pass metabolism can significantly reduce the amount of active drug available to exert its therapeutic effects, leading to lower bioavailability and, consequently, suboptimal clinical outcomes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased renal clearance: While increased renal clearance can lead to faster elimination of a drug from the body, it does not directly affect the initial bioavailability of an orally administered drug. Renal clearance impacts the duration of action and the steady-state concentration of the drug, but not the initial amount that reaches the systemic circulation.

Option B - High protein binding: High protein binding affects the distribution of the drug in the body and the proportion of the drug that is free versus bound to plasma proteins. It influences the drug's pharmacodynamics and duration of action but does not directly impact the initial absorption and bioavailability.

Option D - Acidic environment in the stomach: While the acidic environment in the stomach can affect the stability and dissolution of certain drugs, leading to potential issues with absorption, it is less likely to be the primary factor compared to extensive first-pass metabolism, especially for a drug known to undergo significant hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: A transverse section of an embryo post-gastrulation is shown below. Which of the following is not a derivative of the structure labelled ‘A’ in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Neurohypophysis:

  • The above image shows a transverse section of the embryo post gastrulation with the mesodermal layer labelled ‘A’. The neurohypophysis is derived from the neural plate ectoderm.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Parietal pleura: The parietal pleura is a derivative of the dorsal somatic lateral plate mesoderm.

Option B - Visceral peritoneum: The visceral peritoneum is a derivative of the ventral somatic lateral plate mesoderm.

Option C - Ovaries: The ovaries are a derivative of the intermediate mesoderm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a late sign of congenital syphilis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Hepatosplenomegaly:

  • Hepatosplenomegaly is an early sign of congenital syphilis infection.

Early signs of congenital syphilis

  • Hepatosplenomegaly and Jaundice
  • Diffuse lymphadenopathy
  • Painful osteochondritis & periostitis can lead to pseudo paralysis
  • Skin lesions: Mucocutaneous erythematous maculopapular or vesiculobullous lesions (involving head and feet) followed by desquamation (shedding/scaling)

Late signs of congenital syphilis: from head to toe

  • Olympian brow (prominent forehead)
  • Saddle nose
  • Hutchinson's triad
    • Hutchinson's teeth(notched incisors)
    • Interstitial keratitis
    • Sensorineural deafness
  • Rhagades: Spoke like
  • Higoumenakis'sign - Thickening of the medial 1/3rd or sternal end of clavicle.
  • Clutton joints involving knee (painless)
  • Sabre shins i.e., anterior bowing of tibia

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are late signs of congenital syphilis.

questions.text: A research study is conducted to examine the association between smoking and the development of lung cancer. Among 500 individuals who are regular smokers,50 individuals developed lung cancer. Among 500 individuals who are non-smokers,10 individuals developed lung cancer. What is the interpretation?

choices.text: Individuals who smoke are 5 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers
Individuals who smoke are 10 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers
Individuals who smoke are 2 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers
Individuals who smoke have the same risk of developing lung cancer as non-smokers.

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Individuals who smoke are 5 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers:

  • Study on smoking and lung cancer,
    • If RR=5, smokers are at 5 times more risk of lung cancer than non-smokers.
    • If RR=1, whether a person smokes or does not smoke has nothing to do with lung cancer.
    • If RR=0.25 (75% reduction in incidence rate among exposed compared to non-exposed) protective factor.
  • Calculation of Relative Risk (RR):

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Individuals who smoke are 10 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers: This statement is not accurate based on the calculated relative risk, which is 5.

Option C -Individuals who smoke are 2 times more likely to develop lung cancer compared to non-smokers: This statement is not accurate based on the calculated relative risk, which is 5.

Option D - Individuals who smoke have the same risk of developing lung cancer as non-smokers: This statement is not accurate based on the calculated relative risk, which indicates a higher risk in smokers.

questions.text: Mark the incorrect statement regarding the external ear in a child:

choices.text: Cavum concha is the biggest depression in the external ear.
The purpose of the Lempert endaural incision is to prevent cartilaginous necrosis.
External auditory canal is straightened for visualization of the tympanic membrane by pulling it upwards and outwards.
Tympanic membrane is placed at an angle of 45 degrees.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - External auditory canal is straightened for visualization of the tympanic membrane by pulling it upwards and outwards:

  • The EAC is S-shaped, so it is necessary to straighten the canal before visualizing. To do so, the pinna is stretched upwards, backward, and outwards in adult patients. In children, the pinna is stretched downwards and backward because the bony portion of the external auditory canal has not been fully developed.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B & D are correct regarding the external ear.

questions.text: Which of the following is a common complication of ulcerative colitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Toxic megacolon:

  • Toxic megacolon is a common complication of ulcerative colitis characterized by massive distension of the colon, leading to ischemia and necrosis, which ultimately causes a perforation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are rarely seen in Ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding seminoma?

choices.text: Ultrasound typically reveals a hyperechoic mass in relation to the testis
Fine-needle aspiration (FNAC) is recommended to confirm diagnosis
High inguinal orchidectomy is performed even on suspicion of testicular tumor due to the high likelihood of malignancy
The primary landing site for lymph node metastasis from a left testicular tumor is the inter-aortocaval lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - High inguinal orchidectomy is performed even on suspicion of testicular tumor due to the high likelihood of malignancy:

  • High inguinal orchidectomy is performed even on suspicion of testicular tumor because most testicular tumors are malignant, and this surgical approach helps prevent tumor spread.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ultrasound typically reveals a hyperechoic mass in relation to the testis:

  • Ultrasound usually shows a hypoechoic mass in relation to the testis, not hyperechoic.

Option B - Fine-needle aspiration (FNAC) or trans-scrotal biopsy is recommended to confirm diagnosis:

  • FNAC or trans scrotal biopsy is contraindicated because it can cause seeding of tumor cells along the tract, leading to inguinal lymph node metastasis.

Option D - The primary landing site for lymph node metastasis from a left testicular tumor is the inter-aortocaval lymph nodes:

  • The primary landing site for lymph node metastasis from a left testicular tumor is the para-aortic lymph nodes, not the inter-aortocaval lymph nodes.

questions.text: A  20-year-old  sexually active male patient presents with complaints of a genital ulcer. On examination, there is no inguinal lymphadenopathy, and the ulcer is painless and bleeds easily to the touch. What is the treatment of choice for this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Azithromycin 1 gram daily for one week
Azithromycin 1 gram per week for 3 weeks
Doxycycline 100 mg daily for one week
Doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for one week

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Azithromycin 1 gram per week for 3 weeks:

  • The likely diagnosis in this patient is donovanosis also known as granuloma venereum/granuloma inguinale and the treatment of choice for this condition is Azithromycin 1 gram per week for 3 weeks or 500mg daily for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have resolved. Alternatively, it can also be treated with Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for at least 3 weeks and until all lesions have healed.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A:

  • The treatment of choice is for granuloma inguinale is Azithromycin 1 gram per week for 3 weeks or 500mg daily for at least 3 weeks.

Option C and D:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice a day for at least 3 can be an alternate treatment however, the treatment of choice is azithromycin 1 gram per week for 3 weeks or 500mg daily for at least 3 weeks.

questions.text: To which stage of the demographic transition model does the term "demographic trap" refer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Early Expanding:

  • The term "demographic trap" refers to a situation where a country gets stuck in Stage II (early expanding) of the demographic transition model.
  • During this stage, the crude birth rate (CBR) remains high while the crude death rate (CDR) begins to decline.

Incorrect Options:

Option A Stage I: High Stationary

  • When a country forms, birth and death rates are both high (CBR and CDR)
  • The population is stable.

Option C Stage III: Late expanding

  • CBR starts to decline due to family planning services put in place.
  • The population is still growing but at a slower rate

Option D Stage IV: Low Stationary.

  • A stable population with low CDR and CBR

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female presents with a pulsatile mass in her left middle ear associated with hearing loss and intermittent episodes of severe vertigo. Otoscopic examination reveals a reddish-blue mass behind the tympanic membrane. The CECT head of the patient is given below:



Which radiological finding is observed in this image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Phelp’s sign:

  • The clinical findings are consistent with the diagnosis of glomus tumor, and the given image of the CECT head showing the Phelp sign confirms the diagnosis. The erosion of the carotico-jugular spine bone is called the Phelps sign.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Salt and pepper appearance: Salt and pepper appearance is seen in the glomus tumor on MRI, not CECT. It occurs as a result of areas that are white and areas that are gray due to the microhemorrhages that happen within the tumor.

Option B - Aquino’s sign: It is a clinical sign, not a radiological sign of a glomus tumor.

Option D - Hitzelberger sign: It is a clinical sign seen in Acoustic neuroma, not a radiological sign.

questions.text: Which fungal infection is most likely causing a 42-year-old female gardener's fever, fatigue, dry cough, elevated temperature, diffuse bilateral lung crackles, diffuse reticulonodular opacities on chest X-ray, and intracellular yeast forms in macrophages on the sputum sample?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Histoplasmosis:

  • The patient's presentation is suggestive of a respiratory infection. The exposure to areas with bird droppings is common amongst gardeners and the presence of intracellular yeast forms within macrophages in the sputum sample strongly suggest Histoplasma capsulatum infection, which is known to cause histoplasmosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Blastomycosis: Blastomycosis is caused by Blastomyces dermatitidis and typically presents with symptoms like pneumonia. It shows Broad Based budding on microscopy.

Option B - Coccidioidomycosis: Coccidioidomycosis, caused by Coccidioides species, is commonly known as "Valley fever." On microscopy, barrel-shaped arthrospores are seen.

Option C - Aspergillosis: Aspergillosis is caused by Aspergillus species and shows Acute angle dichotomous branching with septate hyphae on microscopy.

questions.text: A syndrome characterized by the delusional belief that the spouse or sexual partner is unfaithful ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Othello syndrome: Othello syndrome involves a delusional belief that the spouse or sexual partner is unfaithful.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ekbom’s syndrome: Ekbom’s syndrome is also known as delusional parasitosis, where the individual believes that they are infested with parasites.

Option B - De Clerambault’s syndrome:De Clerambault’s syndrome is also called erotomania. In this syndrome, the person has a delusional belief that someone, usually of higher status, is in love with them.

Option C - Querulous paranoia: Querulous paranoia is characterized by a paranoid attitude marked by a litigious disposition and a tendency to make unreasonable complaints.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male presents with chronic cough, hemoptysis, and weight loss. A chest X-ray reveals a peripherally located mass in the right lung. A biopsy of the lesion showed an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation. The immunohistochemistry sample tested positive for CK 7 and TTF1. Which of the following is least likely to be mutated in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - CDKN2A:

  • The features in the biopsy showing an invasive malignant epithelial tumor with glandular differentiation and IHC testing positive for CK7 and TTF1 are indicative of adenocarcinoma of the lung.
  • And hence the least likely mutation seen in adenocarcinoma lung is the CDKN2A mutation.
  • CDKN2A, which codes for the p16 protein, is commonly implicated in squamous cell carcinoma of the lung, pancreatic cancer, and melanoma.
  • Other positive tumor markers for adenocarcinoma lung include MUC1 and NAPSINA

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D – KRAS, EGFR and RET:

  • In Adenocarcinoma of the lung, a gain of function mutation in multiple genes encoding Receptor Tyrosine Kinases including EGFR, ALK, ROS, MET, and RET are seen. Tumors without Tyrosine kinase gene mutation often have KRAS gene mutations.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to her gynecologist with abnormal vaginal bleeding. She reports postcoital bleeding and occasional spotting between periods. She has not experienced any pelvic pain or discomfort but is concerned about the irregular bleeding. On further examination, the lesion was found to be >4cm limited to the cervix. What is the most likely treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Chemoradiation:

  • The scenario is suggestive of the patient in stage 1B3
  • The most appropriate treatment for this stage is chemoradiation

Incorrect Options:

Option A and D:

  • Radical Trachelectomy or Conization is done for stage 1A 1

Option B - Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD:

  • Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD is done for stage IB2

questions.text: Which of the following does not pass through the floor of the structure marked ‘X’ in the given image?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mandibular nerve:

  • The structure marked ‘X’ in the above image is the foramen lacerum and the mandibular nerve does not pass through the floor of this foramina. The mandibular nerve passes through the foramen ovale.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Greater petrosal Nerve: This structure passes through the floor of the foramen lacerum.

Option B - Deep Petrosal Nerve: This structure passes through the floor of the foramen lacerum.

Option C - Vidian Nerve: This structure passes through the floor of the foramen lacerum.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman was started on a COCP regimen and took a pill at 8 pm on day 1. She forgot to take the pill on day 2, and by 1 pm on day 3, she realized she missed the previous night's dose. She is currently in the first week of her COCP cycle. What would be the most appropriate next step in managing her situation?

choices.text: No need to take the missed pill and continue with her regular pill at 8 pm
Use the barrier method for the next 7 days
Take the missed pill at 1 pm and at night, she can take her regular pill

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Take the missed pill at 1 pm and at night, she can take her regular pill:

  • She can take the missed pill as soon as she remembers. At night, she can take her regular pill.
  • This means she can take two pills a day.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - No need to take the missed pill and continue with her regular pill at 8 pm:

  • She must take the missed pill along with the regular pill

Option B - Emergency contraception is required:

  • Emergency contraception is only required In case of unprotected sex in the last 72 hours when she Miss >= 3 pills in ﬁrst or second week or started new pack 3 days late

Option C - Use the barrier method for the next 7 days:

  • If she misses more than equal to 2 pills, she needs to take a barrier method.

questions.text: All of the following can cause White-Out Hemithorax in chest X-rays except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Pneumothorax:

  • Pneumothorax causes Black- Out Hemithorax, not White-Out Hemithorax
  • Conditions in which black-out hemithorax is seen :
    • Hyperinflation
      • COPD (bilateral)
      • Foreign body
      • Pneumothorax
    • Decreased vascular markings
      • Pulmonary embolism 
    • Decreased density
      • Mastectomy
      •  Poland syndrome
    • Technical
      •  Incorrect position (rotation)

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are associated with White-Out Hemithorax

White-Out Hemithorax

Causes:

  • Consolidation
  • Collapse
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumonectomy

questions.text: Which of the following options accurately describes the flowchart representation of the Papez circuit?

choices.text: Hippocampus →Fornix→Mamillary bodies→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Anterior cingulate gyrus→ Entorhinal cortex→Hippocampus
Hippocampus→Mamillary bodies→Fornix→Anterior cingulate gyrus→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Entorhinal cortex→Hippocampus
Hippocampus→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Fornix→Mamillary bodies→Anterior cingulate gyrus→Entorhhinal cortex→Hippocaampus
Hippocampus→Fornix→Entorhinal cortex→Mamillary bodies→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Anterior cingulate gyrus→Hippocampus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hippocampus →Fornix→Mamillary bodies→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Anterior cingulate gyrus→ Entorhinal cortex→Hippocampus:

  • The Papez circuit is a part of the limbic system and plays an important role in the consolidation of memory, processing emotions, olfaction, and behavior.
  • The Papez circuit is a corticocortical loop that passes through the thalamus. It begins at the hippocampus→Fornix→Mamillary bodies→Anterior nucleus of the thalamus→Anterior cingulate gyrus→Entorhinal cortex and terminates at the hippocampus.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D: This option is incorrect and the correct pathway has been described above.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with a history of long-term tampon usage now presented with a high fever, rash, and confusion. Where does the staphylococcal enterotoxin bind to the T-cell receptor in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B – Site 2:

  • According to the clinical picture, the patient is suffering from Toxic shock syndrome due to long-term tampon usage. In these cases, the staphylococcal endotoxin acts as a superantigen, leading to the activation of a very large number of T cells.
  • The superantigen binds directly to the lateral aspect of the TCR β instead of binding to the αβ heterodimer groove of the MHC II molecule, as seen with the conventional antigen.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are not the site for the attachment of the superantigen.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman underwent a CT scan for dull, aching pain in her abdomen for the past two months. She has no significant medical history. What is the most appropriate management for her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy:

  • The given CT scan image shows a calcified gallbladder, also known as a Porcelain gallbladder. The most appropriate management of Porcelain gallbladder is immediate laparoscopic cholecystectomy, as it increases the risk of malignancy by 6%.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are not preferred management options in porcelain gallbladder.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation is scheduled for labor induction due to post-term pregnancy. Clinical Findings: Cervical Dilation: 1 cm, Effacement: 50%, and Consistency is soft with posterior position and head station at -2. Calculate the bishop score for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 5:

Parameter

1

2

Cervical Position

0

Fetal Station

1

  • The total bishop score is 5 for this patient

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D are incorrect as given above

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of the Planning Cycle in the correct chronological sequence.

1. Evaluation

2. Assessment of resources

3. Establishment of goals and objectives

4. Analysis of the health situation

5. Programming and implementation
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 4-3-2-5-1:

The steps of the Planning Cycle in the correct chronological sequence include 

 

1. Analysis of the health situation

2. Set Objectives and goals

3. Assessment of resources

4. Deciding priorities

5. Formulate a plan

6. Programming and implementation

7. Monitoring

8. Evaluation

 

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option B, C & D are incorrect as the correct sequence is given above.

questions.text: What is the most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 460-490 nm:

  • The most effective wavelength of light for phototherapy in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia is 460-490 nm.
  • Phototherapy is the mainstay of treatment in neonates with hyperbilirubinemia and it is highly effective. Phototherapy works by the following mechanisms:
    • Configurational isomerization: Z- isomers of bilirubin are converted into nontoxic E isomers.
    • Structural isomerization: Bilirubin is converted into lumirubin which can be rapidly excreted from the body.
  • Phototherapy can be effectively delivered with CFL/LED lamps emitting a 460-490nm wavelength.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D:

  • These options are incorrect and the correct values have been mentioned in the explanation above.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male complained of knee pain and instability after a recent injury to his right knee during a soccer game. On examination, his right knee is swollen, and there is tenderness along the joint line. The range of motion is limited due to pain. An x-ray of his knee is given below. Which of the following is the most sensitive clinical test for diagnosing this patient?
questions.solution:
