Correct Option D - Lachman Test:

  • Given the scenario of a recent injury, knee pain, swelling, and tenderness along the joint line, the Lachman test is often favored for its sensitivity in detecting ACL injuries.
  • This test is considered one of the most sensitive examinations for detecting ACL injuries.
  • The patient's knee is flexed to 20-30 degrees, and the examiner applies an anterior force to the tibia while stabilizing the femur. A positive Lachman test indicates increased anterior translation of the tibia, suggesting an ACL injury.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are less sensitive in detecting ACL injuries.

  1. Anterior Drawer Test:

    • Explanation: This test also assesses the integrity of the ACL.
    • Why Incorrect: While useful, it is less sensitive than the Lachman test. The knee is flexed to 90 degrees, and the examiner pulls the tibia forward. This test can be influenced by hamstring muscle tension, which may limit its diagnostic accuracy.

  2. Pivot Shift Test:

    • Explanation: This test assesses the ACL by evaluating the stability of the knee joint during a simulated pivot.
    • Why Incorrect: It is specific but less sensitive and more difficult to perform accurately, especially in an acutely injured and painful knee. It requires patient relaxation and can be challenging in an office setting.

  3. McMurray Test:

    • Explanation: This test is used to diagnose meniscal tears.
    • Why Incorrect: The McMurray test involves flexing and extending the knee while applying a valgus or varus force, often eliciting a click or pain if a meniscus tear is present. It is not sensitive for ACL injuries.

questions.text: Which of the following is a branch of the posterior division of the internal iliac artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Superior Gluteal:

  • Posterior Division Internal Iliac Artery Branches
    • Superior Gluteal
    • IlioLumbar
    • Lateral Sacral

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C and D are the branches of anterior division of internal iliac artery.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman has recently become preoccupied with a powerful belief that her boss deeply loves her despite the absence of any clear signs of romantic interest from her boss.Which of the following is the appropriate term for this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Declerambault's Syndrome:

  • Declerambault's syndrome, also known as Erotomania, is a psychiatric disorder characterized by a delusional belief that someone, often with higher social or professional standing, is deeply in love with the affected individual.
  • Despite evidence to the contrary, the person maintains and defends this delusional belief.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Othello's Syndrome:

  • Othello's Syndrome, also known as delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy, is a psychiatric disorder characterized by a strong and irrational belief that a romantic partner is unfaithful, despite little or no supporting evidence.
  • Prolonged alcohol use has been linked to this condition.

Option C - Syndrome of intermetamorphosis:

  • The patient believes that others undergo changes in physical and psychological identities into entirely different people.

Option D - Syndrome of subjective doubles:

  • It is the delusional belief of the existence of physical duplicates of self, living in different parts of the world.

questions.text: Removal of which of the following structures will result in sham rage reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Cerebral cortex:

  • In humans, the rage center is held under check by the cerebral cortex. Thus, the cerebral cortex inhibits rage centers under normal circumstances
  • In case of decortication (removal of the cerebral cortex) of an animal during any experiment, there will not be any negative effect on the rage center and excessive rage can be witnessed. This is called a sham rage reaction.

Incorrect Options:

Options A and B - Ventromedial nuclei of the hypothalamus and Lateral nuclei of the hypothalamus:

  • Removal of the cortex leads to sham rage, and removing the hypothalamus leads to placidity in any animal.

Option D - Periaqueductal grey matter:

  • Periaqueductal grey matter (PAG) and periventricular zone of the thalamus and hypothalamus are known as punishment centers.

questions.text: What is the most common genetic alteration seen in prostate cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hypermethylation of GSTP1:

  • In prostate cancer, hypermethylation of the GSTP1 gene promoter region is the most common genetic alteration observed.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are not commonly seen in seen in prostate cancer.

questions.text: According to the Gharbi classification, which grade of hydatid cyst is visible in the ultrasound shown below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Grade 2:

  • The given ultrasound image shows a floating membrane that resembles a waterlily or a water snake. This characteristic appearance is seen in Grade 2 of the hydatid cyst.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Grade 1: Grade 1 shows simple fluid collection.

Option C - Grade 3: Grade 3 shows a multiloculated cyst with a honeycomb appearance.

Option D - Grade 4: Grade 4 shows a complex heterogeneous mass.

questions.text: All of the following are highly radiosensitive tumors except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D – Osteosarcoma:

  • Osteosarcoma is a highly radioresistant tumor

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B and C are incorrect as these are highly radiosensitive tumors

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with an 11-week pregnancy presents to the emergency department with a 3-day history of uterine bleeding. On physical examination, the physician notices that the uterus is larger than normal for gestational age. According to the USG below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Complete mole:

  • The absence of a fetus, the enlarged uterus, and the presence of a snowstorm appearance on ultrasound (a characteristic pattern of hydatidiform mole) are indicative of a complete mole.
  • A complete mole occurs when an empty egg is fertilized by a sperm, resulting in a complete absence of fetal tissue.
  • The entire conceptus is made up of paternal chromosomes, leading to a diploid (46,XX) karyotype.
  • In a complete mole, there is an overgrowth of trophoblastic tissue (placenta) with no identifiable fetus.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Partial mole:

  • Partial mole refers to a pregnancy with an abnormal embryo and some normal placental tissue.
  • It is characterized by triploid karyotype (69XXX or 69XXY).
  • Typically, partial moles have fetal tissue but with abnormalities.

Option C - Invasive mole:

  • Invasive mole refers to the extension of trophoblastic tissue into the myometrium (muscular wall) of the uterus.
  • It is more aggressive than a complete mole and may invade surrounding tissues.

Option D – Choriocarcinoma:

  • Choriocarcinoma is a malignant tumor arising from trophoblastic cells.
  • It can occur after a molar pregnancy (complete or partial) or a normal pregnancy.
  • Choriocarcinoma can invade locally or metastasize to distant organs.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common constituent of pancreatic stone?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Calcium carbonate:

  • Calcium carbonate is the most common type of pancreatic stone. Pancreatic stones, also known as pancreatic calculi, can form in the pancreatic ducts due to various factors such as chronic pancreatitis, alcohol consumption, or metabolic disorders. These stones can obstruct the flow of pancreatic enzymes and bile, leading to complications such as pancreatitis or bile duct obstruction.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are not the most common constituents of pancreatic stones.

  1. Cholesterol:

    • Explanation: Cholesterol stones are typically found in the gallbladder and are a common type of gallstone.
    • Why Incorrect: Cholesterol is not a common constituent of pancreatic stones.

  2. Uric acid:

    • Explanation: Uric acid stones are more commonly found in the urinary tract, particularly in patients with gout or hyperuricemia.
    • Why Incorrect: Uric acid is not a common constituent of pancreatic stones.

  3. Calcium phosphate:

    • Explanation: Calcium phosphate stones can form in the kidneys and urinary tract but are less common than calcium carbonate stones in the pancreas.
    • Why Incorrect: While calcium phosphate can be found in some types of stones, it is not the most common constituent of pancreatic stones.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient with breast cancer is undergoing chemotherapy with doxorubicin. After her fourth cycle of treatment, she reports experiencing significant fatigue, shortness of breath, and swelling in her legs. The physician suspects that these symptoms are related to a common adverse effect of doxorubicin therapy.Which of the following is the most likely adverse effect of doxorubicin in this patient, and what is the recommended management strategy?

choices.text: Cardiotoxicity; Regular cardiac monitoring and ACE inhibitors
Hepatotoxicity; Dose adjustment and liver function tests
Neurotoxicity; Vitamin supplementation and physical therapy

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cardiotoxicity; Regular cardiac monitoring and ACE inhibitors:

  • Doxorubicin is an anthracycline chemotherapeutic agent that is known for its potential to cause cardiotoxicity, which can manifest as congestive heart failure.
  • Symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath, and leg swelling are indicative of heart failure.
  • The management strategy includes regular cardiac monitoring (e.g., echocardiograms, measurement of ejection fraction) to detect early signs of cardiotoxicity.
  • If cardiotoxicity is detected, the use of cardioprotective agents such as ACE inhibitors can help manage and mitigate cardiac dysfunction.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nephrotoxicity; Hydration and diuretics: Nephrotoxicity is not a common adverse effect of doxorubicin. It is more commonly associated with drugs like cisplatin. Hydration and diuretics are used to manage nephrotoxicity but are not relevant for doxorubicin.

Option C - Hepatotoxicity; Dose adjustment and liver function tests: While hepatotoxicity can occur with certain chemotherapeutic agents, it is not the primary concern with doxorubicin. Liver function tests are important for monitoring hepatotoxicity, but they are not the mainstay for managing doxorubicin-induced adverse effects.

Option D - Neurotoxicity; Vitamin supplementation and physical therapy: Neurotoxicity is a common side effect of drugs like vincristine and paclitaxel, which can cause peripheral neuropathy. Management includes vitamin supplementation and physical therapy. However, neurotoxicity is not a typical adverse effect of doxorubicin.

questions.text: A 55-year-old Male with a history of Type 2 Diabetes and hypertension has been Enrolled in the diabetes management program for the past 6 months. It includes collecting data on his glycemic control, medication adherence, and healthcare utilization in the 6 months preceding his enrollment in the program along with Ongoing data collection during the 6-month participation period, including glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) levels, lifestyle changes, and the frequency of healthcare visits. Which of the following is the most appropriate term for this study?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ambispective Cohort Study:

  • Definition: An ambispective cohort study combines elements of both retrospective and prospective cohort studies. It involves collecting historical data (retrospective) and continues with ongoing data collection (prospective).
  • The study design aligns with both retrospective (baseline data) and prospective (follow-up data) components, making it ambispective.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Prospective Cohort Study:

  • Definition: In a prospective cohort study, participants are enrolled, and data are collected moving forward in time.
  • While there is ongoing data collection during the 6-month participation period, the study also involves collecting retrospective data on the patient's history in the 6 months preceding enrollment. Therefore, it is not purely prospective.

Option B - Retrospective Cohort Study:

  • In a retrospective cohort study, researchers look at historical data to identify possible causes or risk factors.
  • The study involves both retrospective (baseline data) and prospective (follow-up data) components. It combines historical data with ongoing data collection.

Option D - Non-concurrent Cohort Study:

  • Non-concurrent cohort studies are also known as Retrospective Cohort study
  • The study focuses on a single cohort (the patient) over time rather than comparing multiple cohorts at different points.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Hepatopulmonary Syndrome (HPS) is correct?

choices.text: The primary cause of hypoxia in HPS is the reduction in pulmonary blood flow due to vasoconstriction.
Platypnea and orthodeoxia in HPS are due to the uniform distribution of blood flow in the lungs when the patient is lying flat.
The overproduction of endothelial nitric oxide synthase enzyme leads to the dilation of pulmonary vessels, contributing to intrapulmonary shunting in HPS.
Hepatopulmonary Syndrome is primarily characterized by increased pulmonary blood vessel diameter leading to hyperoxia.

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - The overproduction of endothelial nitric oxide synthase enzyme leads to the dilation of pulmonary vessels, contributing to intrapulmonary shunting in HPS:

  • In HPS, the overproduction of endothelial nitric oxide synthase leads to increased synthesis of nitric oxide. This causes dilation of pulmonary vessels, which contributes to intrapulmonary shunting where red blood cells do not get adequately oxygenated as they pass through the dilated vessels, leading to hypoxia.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The primary cause of hypoxia in HPS is the reduction in pulmonary blood flow due to vasoconstriction: The primary cause of hypoxia in HPS is not due to a reduction in pulmonary blood flow from vasoconstriction. Instead, it is due to the dilation of pulmonary vessels, which causes intrapulmonary shunting, where red blood cells pass through the vessels without being adequately oxygenated.

Option B - Platypnea and orthodeoxia in HPS are due to the uniform distribution of blood flow in the lungs when the patient is lying flat: Platypnea (difficulty breathing when sitting up) and orthodeoxia (decrease in arterial oxygen when sitting up) occur because gravity causes blood to pool in the lower parts of the lungs when sitting, increasing the effect of intrapulmonary shunting. When lying flat, blood flow is more evenly distributed, temporarily reducing the shunt effect.

Option D - Hepatopulmonary Syndrome is primarily characterized by increased pulmonary blood vessel diameter leading to hyperoxia: Hepatopulmonary Syndrome is characterized by increased pulmonary blood vessel diameter, which results in hypoxia, not hyperoxia. The enlarged vessel diameters allow red blood cells to pass through without sufficient oxygenation, leading to low oxygen levels in the blood.

questions.text: Which ratio describes the effective transformation of sound energy from the tympanic membrane to the footplate of stapes?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Areal ratio:

  • The areal ratio is the effective transformation of sound energy from the tympanic membrane to the footplate of the stapes in the middle ear. This ratio is essential for optimizing the transfer of sound waves from the air-filled middle ear to the fluid-filled inner ear.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Lever ratio: The ratio between malleus to incus (M: I) is called the Lever ratio.

Option C - Total transformation ratio: Total transformer ratio = Areal ratio × Lever ratio

Option D - Phase difference ratio: Phase difference refers to the difference in time created by the transmission of sound from the oval window to the round window.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her physician with complaints of memory loss and difficulty with everyday tasks. Her family reports that she often repeats questions and misplaces items. On mental status examination, she demonstrates impaired short-term memory and difficulty recalling recent events. The patient eventually dies, and brain samples obtained from the patient show the following features.


	
		
			
			1.
			
			
			
			
		
		
			
			2.
			
			
			
			
		
	


Choose the option that matches the structures demonstrated and their composition.

choices.text: 1. Hirano Body- Actin, 2. Flame cells- Hyperphosphorylated Tau protein
1. Neurofibrillary tangle- Tau protein, 2. Neuritic plaque- Amyloid core
1. Neuritic plaque- Amyloid core, 2. Neurofibrillary tangle- Tau protein
1. Flame cells- Hyperphosphorylated Tau protein, 2. Hirano Body- Actin

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1. Flame cells- Hyperphosphorylated Tau protein, 2. Hirano Body- Actin:

  • The age of the patient and impaired short-term memory give a likely diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease.
  • Characteristic findings seen in brain samples of Alzheimer's disease are: 

1. Flame cells - are neurofibrillary tangles made of Hyperphosphorylated Tau protein

 

2. Hirano Body- These are needle-shaped bodies, it is composed of Actin.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and C are incorrect.

questions.text: A 6-month-old child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of irritability and lethargy between feeds and a protuberant abdomen. On examination, the pediatrician notes a doll-like appearance of the child’s face and hepatomegaly. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of triglycerides, hyperuricemia, and lactic acidosis. What is the likely affected enzyme in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Glucose-6-phosphatase:

The enzyme likely affected in this child is Glucose-6-phosphatase; the diagnosis is Von Gierke’s disease(type 1a).

  • Patients with Von Gierke’s typically present with features such as:
    • Hepatomegaly → due to glycogen deposition in the hepatocytes
    • Hypoglycemia → early morning or in between feeds. Parents usually report irritability and lethargy in between feeds. Seizures may also be seen due to hypoglycemia.
    • Hypertriglyceridemia → Enhanced de novo lipogenesis due to excess glucose-6-phosphate being converted into triglycerides
    • Hyperuricemia → Excess Glucose 6 phosphate enters the pentose phosphate pathway and is converted into ribose-5-phosphate, which causes an overproduction of purines and a buildup of uric acid.
    • Lactic acidosis → Excess Glucose-6-phosphate gets converted into pyruvate, eventually converted into lactate.
    • The doll-like appearance of facies due to fat deposition.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Branching enzyme:

  • A branching enzyme deficiency leads to a type 4 glycogen storage disorder(Amylopectinosis/Anderson’s disease). There is deposition of an amylopectin-like structure in the liver. Most children are symptomatic by 3 years of age and present with chronic liver disease and portal hypertension.

Option B - Debranching enzyme:

  • A deficiency of the debranching enzyme leads to Cori’s disease. Although hepatomegaly may be seen, these patients also present with splenomegaly, muscle involvement, elevated levels of CPK and transaminases.

Option C - Acid maltase:

  • A deficiency of acid maltase (alpha 1,4 glucosidase) leads to Pompes disease. Patients present with features of diverse systemic involvement such as cardiomegaly, hepatomegaly, and hypotonia.

questions.text: All of the following are types of incisions made to perform an autopsy, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Modified ‘I’ shaped:

  • A modified ‘I’ shaped incision is not a type of incision made to perform an autopsy.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - ‘I’ shaped:

  • Incision extending from the chin straight down to the symphysis pubis.
  • It is the most common type of incision.

Option B - ‘Y’ shaped:

  • 2 incisions each starting from acromion processes, meet in the midline near the xiphisternum and then extend downwards straight.

Option D - Modified ‘Y’ shaped:

  • It is used when a detailed study of the neck is required e.g., Asphyxial death due to neck compression (hanging or strangulation).

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male presents with complaints of gradual hearing loss over the past few years. His medical history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes. During the pure-tone audiometry, the following findings can be seen:



What is the most likely type of hearing loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Sensorineural hearing loss:

  • The given scenario, with pure tone audiometry showing a downward-sloping graph without an AB gap, is suggestive of presbycusis. Presbycusis is an age-related Sensory Neural Hearing Loss.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as explained.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Bochdalek hernia is correct?

choices.text: It is most commonly seen on the right side of the diaphragm
Bag and mask ventilation is considered safe
It is characterized by the herniation of left-sided structures

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - It is characterized by the herniation of left-sided structures:

  • Bochdalek hernia is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and is also known as a left-sided posterolateral hernia. It occurs due to the failure of fusion of the pleuroperitoneal canal on the left side, leading to the herniation of left-sided structures such as the spleen, stomach, and transverse colon above the diaphragm. Dysphagia is not typically associated with Bochdalek hernia. Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in these patients due to the risk of lung collapse.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are incorrect, as explained above.

questions.text: A 16-year-old adolescent female presents to the gynecologist with a complaint of irregular menstrual cycles since menarche, with unpredictable and heavy bleeding. She mentions that her periods last longer than a week, and she experiences significant discomfort and cramping during menstruation. Which of the following is the ﬁrst line management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Tranexamic acid:

  • Tranexamic acid is an antifibrinolytic medication that inhibits the conversion of plasminogen to plasmin, a key enzyme involved in fibrinolysis (breakdown of blood clots).
  • It works by stabilizing blood clots and preventing their premature breakdown.
  • In the context of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB), tranexamic acid is considered a first-line drug for management.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Oral Contraceptives:

  • Oral contraceptives, particularly combined hormonal contraceptives containing estrogen and progestin, are commonly used to regulate menstrual cycles in adolescents with AUB.
  • They provide hormonal stability, reduce menstrual blood loss, and help in managing symptoms.
  • This is not often considered as the first-line management for AUB in adolescents.

Option C - Progesterone:

  • Progesterone therapy, often in the form of progestin-containing medications, is another approach to regulate menstrual cycles and reduce heavy bleeding.
  • It helps in balancing the hormonal environment in the uterus and is commonly used in the management of AUB, especially when estrogen-progestin contraceptives are not suitable.
  • But the first line of management is tranexamic acid

Option D - Endometrial Biopsy:

  • Endometrial ablative procedures is preferred in older women.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old male patient undergoing chemotherapy for colorectal cancer reports severe nausea and vomiting despite receiving standard antiemetic treatment. His oncologist decides to add palonosetron to his regimen to better control his chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting (CINV).

What is the primary mechanism by which palonosetron helps in controlling CINV in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Serotonin (5-HT3) receptor antagonism:

  • Palonosetron is a selective serotonin (5-HT3) receptor antagonist.
  • It works by blocking the action of serotonin, a natural substance that can cause nausea and vomiting, especially in the context of chemotherapy.
  • By inhibiting these receptors, palonosetron effectively reduces the incidence and severity of CINV.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dopamine receptor antagonism: Drugs that antagonize dopamine receptors (e.g., metoclopramide) are used as antiemetics, but this is not the mechanism of action of palonosetron.

Option C - Histamine (H1) receptor antagonism: Antihistamines target H1 receptors to treat motion sickness and allergic reactions, but they do not address the serotonin-mediated pathway involved in CINV.

Option D - Acetylcholine (muscarinic) receptor antagonism: Anticholinergic agents, such as scopolamine, block muscarinic receptors to prevent motion sickness and postoperative nausea, but this is not how palonosetron works in CINV.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, swelling of the face and lips, and a widespread rash after eating at a restaurant. She is quickly diagnosed with anaphylaxis. The attending physician decides to administer adrenaline as part of the emergency treatment.

Which of the following is the primary reason for administering adrenaline in this clinical scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - To cause bronchodilation:

  • Adrenaline (epinephrine) is administered in anaphylaxis primarily because it causes bronchodilation, which helps alleviate the severe bronchoconstriction that can occur during an anaphylactic reaction.
  • Additionally, adrenaline helps by increasing peripheral vasoconstriction, reducing swelling, and stabilizing mast cells to prevent further release of mediators.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To decrease heart rate: Adrenaline actually increases heart rate and contractility, which helps maintain blood pressure during anaphylaxis. It is not used to decrease heart rate.

Option C - To reduce blood glucose levels: Adrenaline can actually increase blood glucose levels by stimulating glycogenolysis. It is not used for lowering blood glucose levels.

Option D - To induce sedation: Adrenaline is a sympathomimetic drug that stimulates the nervous system, and it does not have sedative effects. It is not used for inducing sedation.

questions.text: A patient with ulcerative colitis presents with 4 to 6 stools per day, blood in stools, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and no systemic toxicity. Which of the following treatments should be primarily given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Sulfasalazine:

  • Sulfasalazine is a first-line treatment for mild to moderate ulcerative colitis. It is effective in reducing inflammation in the colon, which helps to decrease symptoms such as increased stool frequency and blood in stools.
  • Given the patient's moderate symptoms and absence of systemic toxicity, sulfasalazine is an appropriate choice for initial management.

Incorrect Options:

Option B – Prednisolone:

  • Prednisolone is a corticosteroid used for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, especially when there is systemic toxicity.

Option C - Budesonide:

  • Budesonide is another corticosteroid but with less systemic absorption compared to prednisolone. It is often used for mild to moderate Crohn's disease and certain types of colitis, but sulfasalazine remains more commonly used for ulcerative colitis

Option D - Infliximab infusion:

  • Infliximab is a biologic therapy used for moderate to severe ulcerative colitis, especially when patients do not respond to conventional therapies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 34 weeks of gestation, presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. She has a history of hypertension controlled with medication during this pregnancy. On examination, there is no fetal distress.What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Normal delivery:

  • The above-given scenario is suggestive of placenta abruption. The best management for this patient is by Normal delivery
  • Normal delivery in abruption: A.R.M is done to augment labor by the release of local prostaglandins and also causes the compression of the placenta against the fetus which stops the bleeding
  • Loss of fetal movements (Not equal to fetal distress)

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Conservative management:

  • There is no role of conservative management in abruption at any gestation

Option B - LSCS:

  • Cesarean is done in case of fetal distress. As there are no signs of fetal distress in the question, there is no role of LSCS.

Option D - Tocolytics:

  • Tocolytics are not given in abruption as it can lead to DIC and death eventually.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with a known history of ischemic heart disease presents to the emergency department with complaints of chest pain, shortness of breath, and palpitations.  his blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg with an HR of 180 beats per minute. An ECG was done as given below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - IV Amiodarone:

  • The above scenario and ECG show ventricular tachycardia in a hemodynamically stable patient.
  • Stable ventricular tachycardia
  • Systolic blood pressure >90mmHg
  • IV Amiodarone is preferred in this case

Incorrect Options:

Option A - IV Adenosine:

  • IV Adenosine is given for PSVT, not VT

Option B - Synchronised DC shock:

  • Synchronised DC shock is given for PSVT, not VT in hemodynamically unstable patient

Option C - Asynchronised DC shock:

  • Asynchronised DC shock is given for VT in the hemodynamically unstable patient for systolic BP is < 90mmHg

questions.text: A physician encounters a patient with symptoms indicative of meningococcal meningitis. The physician, at risk due to the mode of transmission through droplets, becomes infected. His mother and wife who is 4 months pregnant are taking care of him. Which of the following is the most appropriate prophylaxis for his mother?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Ciproﬂoxacin:

  • Neisseria meningitidis causes epidemics of meningitis in winter in an overcrowded population.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Ceftriaxone

  • Health workers and pregnant women are given Ceftriaxone.

Option C – Rifampicin:

  • Rifampicin has 70% eﬃcacy and is not recommended for healthcare workers.
  • Family contact can be prevented by using Ciproﬂoxacin.

Option D - Penicillin G:

  • Penicillin G is not given as prophylaxis for Neisseria meningitidis

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl was brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her legs. Her parents also mentioned a history of fractures. On examination, the child appeared pale with a distended abdomen.  Hematological investigations revealed pancytopenia. An X-ray of the femur was ordered, which showed the following finding.



What could be the suspected diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Gaucher’s disease:

  • The diagnosis for the above clinical case could be a suspected Gaucher’s disease. It occurs due to a deficiency of beta-glucosidase
  • This can be explained by symptoms such as bone pain and a history of fractures due to osteopenia and pancytopenia.
  • These children also have distended abdomen due to hepatosplenomegaly. The X-ray image shown above depicts the Erlenmeyer flask deformity of the femur, which almost certainly confirms Gaucher’s disease. This deformity occurs due to widened metaphysis.
  • Gaucher’s disease can further be confirmed by a bone marrow aspiration, which may reveal macrophages with crumpled tissue paper. These macrophages have accumulated glucosylcerebroside membrane inside giving it the characteristic appearance.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Krabbe’s disease: Krabbe’s disease occurs due to the deficiency of beta-galactosidase. It can be differentiated from Gaucher’s disease by the absence of hepatosplenomegaly. Additionally, due to impaired metabolism of myelin, neurological manifestations and cranial nerve involvement leading to deafness and blindness can be observed in Krabbe’s disease.

Option B - Tay Sach’s disease: Tay Sachs disease is a manifestation of a deficiency of the hexosaminidase A enzyme. It also presents with neurological manifestations. Tay-Sachs is the only GM2 ganglioside accumulation disease with a cherry red spot on fundus optic examination.

Option D - Niemann Pick Disease: Although Niemann Pick disease may produce symptoms of hepatomegaly. It occurs due to a defect in the sphingomyelinase enzyme. It is characterized by cherry red spots on fundoscopic examination and zebra body inclusions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man who was on an antibiotic course of ciprofloxacin presented with severe abdominal pain and muscle weakness. He also reported frequent mood changes, confusion, and hallucinations. On further probing, he mentioned his urine is pink in color. Photosensitivity symptoms were ruled out, and abdominal examination was normal. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute intermittent porphyria:

  • The above symptoms of pink urine along with severe abdominal pain, neuropsychiatric manifestations, absent photosensitivity, and history of fluoroquinolone use points to the diagnosis of acute intermittent porphyria.
  • It occurs due to impaired functioning of HMB synthase, also called uroporphyrinogen 1 synthase
  • Drugs that use cytochrome enzymes for metabolism are known to trigger acute intermittent porphyria. These drugs include fluoroquinolones, sulfonamides, barbiturates, etc.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Porphyria cutanea tarda: Porphyria cutanea tarda occurs due to deficiency of uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase. It is characterized by the presence of photosensitivity. It is the most common porphyria.

Option C - Erythropoietic protoporphyria: Erythropoietic protoporphyria occurs due to a defect in ferrochelatase. Although photosensitivity is present here, it is associated with redness and swelling.

Option D - Variegate porphyria: Variegate porphyria occurs due to a defect in Protoporphyrinogen oxidase and presents with both photosensitivity and neurological manifestation

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and malaise. His liver enzymes are elevated. A liver biopsy is performed, showing centrilobular necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration. Another characteristic finding observed is shown in the image given below.



What is the composition of this finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - CK 8/18:

  • The clinical scenario indicates Alcoholic hepatitis, and the histology shows dense eosinophilic intracytoplasmic material which is consistent with Mallory- Denk bodies.
  • Mallory-Denk bodies are known to contain cytokeratins, specifically CK8 and CK18. These cytokeratins are part of the intermediate filament network in hepatocytes and are involved in the structural integrity of the cell. In the context of alcoholic hepatitis, the accumulation of Mallory-Denk bodies is a characteristic histopathological finding.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - CK 4: Cytokeratin 4 is typically associated with stratified epithelia, such as the skin.

Option B - CK 5/6: CK5/6 is often used as a marker for basal cells in stratified epithelia and is not typically associated with hepatocytes.

Option C - CK 7: Cytokeratin 7 is commonly found in glandular epithelia, including the bile ducts.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with rapidly enlarging jaw swelling and abdominal pain. On physical examination, there is a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen. A biopsy of the jaw lesion reveals a starry-sky appearance on histology. Which of the following translocations is likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - t(8;14):

  • Starry sky appearance on histology usually points toward diagnosing Burkitt lymphoma; patient age (12 years) and gender (male) further support the diagnosis. The most common cytogenetic change seen in it is t(8;14).
  • Burkitt lymphoma is an aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma most common in children and young adults, It has two types, endemic and sporadic.
  • The endemic (African) form is characterized by the involvement of the face, especially the maxilla or mandible, and is associated with EBV.
  • The sporadic (Western) form usually involves the abdominal organs such as the ileocecum and peritoneum.
  • The tumor cells are mature B cells that express surface IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, a phenotype consistent with a germinal center B-cell origin.
  • All forms of Burkitt lymphoma are associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - t(15;17):

  • It is found in Acute Myeloid Leukemia and leads to PML/RARA fusion protein production.
  • It leads to the uncontrolled production of leukocytes.

Option B - t(14;18):

  • It is a feature of follicular carcinoma.
  • t(14;18) leads to the overproduction of the BCL gene, which blocks apoptosis.

Option D - t(11;14):

  • t(11;14)/CyclinD1-IGH translocation is a feature of Mantle cell lymphoma.
  • This mutation leads to cyclin D1 overproduction which promotes cells from the G1 phase to the S phase of the cell cycle.

questions.text: A 25-year-old IT executive presents to the OPD with complaints of difficulty concentrating, weakness, and shortness of breath. Respiratory and cardiac examinations were normal. On taking his dietary history, it was found that his meals were mostly processed fast foods which were devoid of green leafy vegetables. On peripheral smear, macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils were discovered. Which of the following findings could best confirm the diagnosis in this case?

choices.text: Elevated urine homocysteine levels, elevated FIGLU levels
Elevated urine homocysteine levels, and elevated urine methylmalonyl levels.
Elevated urine methyl malonyl levels, elevated FIGLU levels
Elevated urine homocysteine levels, elevated urine methyl malonyl levels, Elevated FIGLU levels

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Elevated urine homocysteine levels, elevated FIGLU levels:

  • The above-given history of an IT executive complaining of weakness and difficulty concentrating along with his dietary history of being deficient in green leafy vegetables points to the possibility of folate deficiency.
  • The peripheral smear showing macrocytes and hypersegmented neutrophils also points to the same possibility.
  • Although the peripheral smear findings could also point to vitamin B12 deficiency, a history of a purely vegetarian diet without any supplements would’ve fully attested to the possibility of B12 deficiency.
  • In folate deficiency, homocysteine levels in the blood get elevated and start to escape in the urine. A histidine load test is done to detect folate deficiency. Histidine gets metabolized to FIGLU(Formiminoglutamic acid). FIGLU ultimately forms glutamate with the help of methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Deficiency of folate causes elevated FIGLU levels which get excreted in urine.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Elevated urine homocysteine levels, and elevated urine methylmalonyl levels:

  • Elevated urine homocysteine levels and elevated urine methyl malonyl levels point to the possibility of Vitamin B12 deficiency. Deficiency of vitamin B12 impairs the activity of methionine synthase thus impeding the conversion of homocysteine to methionine. This leads to elevated homocysteine levels in the blood.
  • Methyl-malonyl COA from fatty acids gets converted to succinyl COA with the help of methylmalonyl-COA mutase, which is specifically activated by vitamin B12. In Vit B12 deficiency, this reaction does not occur, leading to elevated methylmalonyl levels.

Option C - Elevated urine methyl malonyl levels, elevated FIGLU levels:

  • Both elevated methylmalonyl levels and elevated FIGLU levels without elevated homocysteine levels would not be found in either vitamin B12 or Vitamin B9 deficiency.

Option D - Elevated urine homocysteine levels, elevated urine methyl malonyl levels, Elevated FIGLU levels:

  • Elevated urine homocysteine levels, elevated urine methylmalonyl levels, and Elevated FIGLU levels would possibly be found in concomitant Vit B12 and Vit B9 deficiency.

questions.text: A 4-year-old child is brought to the ENT clinic with complaints of persistent nasal congestion, headache, and a low-grade fever. On examination, there is tenderness over the bridge of the nose. Which of the following sinuses is most commonly affected in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Ethmoidal sinus:

  • The ethmoidal sinus is the most commonly affected sinus in children.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Frontal sinus: Frontal sinusitis is less common than ethmoidal sinusitis in children.

Option B - Maxillary sinus: Maxillary sinusitis is the most commonly affected sinus in adults, not children.

Option C - Sphenoidal sinus: Sphenoidal sinusitis is the least commonly affected sinus in children as well as adults.

questions.text:
Match the following tumors with their characteristic appearances in X ray imaging   :


	
		
			
			1
			
			
			Sunburst appearance
			
			
			A
			
			
			Osteoclastoma
			
		
		
			
			2
			
			
			Mushroom appearance
			
			
			B
			
			
			Simple bone cyst
			
		
		
			
			3
			
			
			Soap bubble appearance
			
			
			C
			
			
			Osteosarcoma
			
		
		
			
			4
			
			
			Fallen leaf sign
			
			
			D
			
			
			Osteochondroma
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

Osteosarcoma:

  • Shows sunburst or sunray reaction of periosteal reaction.
  • Bony spicules come out perpendicular to the bone.
  • Suggests aggressive bony lesion.

Osteochondroma/Exostosis:

  • Bone outgrowth is continuous with the cortex-mushroom appearance due to the cartilage cap overlying the tumor.

Osteoclastoma/Giant cell tumor

  • The fused skeleton with the growth plate cannot be seen. It affects the articular surface of the wrist joint.
  • Soap bubble appearance is seen because of multiple trabeculations. An eccentric, expansile lesion involving the epiphysis is seen in the image.

Simple bone cyst

 Unfused bone involved and a centrally located lesion.

  • Fracture in the cyst wall or internal septation causes the cyst to move into the dependent part as it is an unilocular cyst showing a fallen leaf sign or trap door sign.
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst is multilocular therefore fallen leaf sign is not seen

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and C are incorrect as given above

questions.text: Which of the following foot muscles is supplied by the medial plantar nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Flexor hallucis brevis:

  • The flexor hallucis brevis is a muscle of the sole. This muscle is responsible for flexing the proximal phalanx of the big toe. It is supplied by the medial plantar nerve

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Abductor digiti minimi: The abductor digiti minimi is responsible for abduction and flexion of the little toe. This muscle is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

Option B - Adductor hallucis: This muscle is responsible for adduction of the big toe and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

Option C - Lumbricals 2, 3 and 4: Lumbrical 1 is supplied by the medial plantar nerve whereas lumbricals 2,3 and 4 are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with complaints of difficulty seeing in dim light conditions and impaired night vision. On examination, the ophthalmologist observes a pale, waxy optic disc, attenuation of arteries and pigmentary disturbance in the form of bony spicules. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Retinitis Pigmentosa:

  • Retinitis Pigmentosa is an autosomal dominant inherited condition characterized by the progressive degeneration of rods and cones in the retina.
  • The symptoms of night blindness(nyctalopia) are typical in this condition.
  • The examination findings of a pale waxy optic disc, attenuation of arteries, and pigmentary disturbance in the form of bony spicules are classic features of Retinitis Pigmentosa.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Age-related macular degeneration (ARMD): ARMD is characterized by degenerative changes at the macula, which is responsible for irreversible vision. The classic findings seen are drusens and retinal detachment.

Option C - Diabetic retinopathy: Diabetic retinopathy is a condition that occurs in individuals with diabetes and is characterized by findings like cotton wool spots, flame shaped hemorrhages, and neovascularization..

Option D - Central serous retinopathy (CSR): CSR is characterized by shallow retinal detachment and accumulation of serous fluid, characterized by metamorphopsia and ring reflex.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with jaundice and right upper quadrant pain. Laboratory tests reveal elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP), Gamma-Glutamyl Transferase (GGT), and 5'nucleotidase levels. What is the investigation of choice for diagnosing her condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography:

  • The given findings are suggestive of choledocholithiasis. MRCP is the investigation of choice for diagnosing choledocholithiasis, Choledochal cyst, Biliary stricture, Cholangiocarcinoma(MRI + MRCP), Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) and Pancreatic divisum.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and C are not the investigation of choice for diagnosing choledocholithiasis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male is found dead in a river. Upon examination, his body exhibits a rigid posture with clenched fists and a hyperextended neck. The surrounding environment suggests drowning. What is the most likely phenomenon observed in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Cadaveric spasm:

  • Cadaveric spasm or antemortem spasm is a phenomenon where muscles contract and fixate in the position they were in at the moment of death. It is often observed in cases of sudden, violent death, such as drowning.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Rigor mortis: Rigor mortis is the stiffening of muscles after death and usually occurs after a few hours. It is not associated with the specific posture described in the scenario.

Option C - Livor mortis: Livor mortis is the settling of blood in the lower parts of the body after death, resulting in a purple discoloration. It doesn't involve muscle contraction or specific postures.

Option D - None of the above

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Para-amino hippuric acid clearance?

choices.text: To measure the RPF through PAH clearance, its concentration should be more than 10 mg/dl
It is reabsorbed at the nephron
Clearance is equal to the GFR
When injected in huge amounts gives falsely low RPF

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - When injected in huge amounts gives falsely low RPF:

  • PAH clearance is maximum approximately 100% so the plasma from where it is cleared out is equal to the amount of the plasma flowing through the kidneys.
  • When given in huge amounts, the secretion at the level of PCT becomes constant after a level because all the transporter proteins are saturated (Tmax) and no more PAH can be secreted, thus giving a low value of clearance which implies less plasma is flowing through the kidney.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - To measure the RPF through PAH clearance, its concentration should be more than 10 mg/dl:

  • To measure the RPF through PAH clearance, its concentration should be less than 10 mg/dl, not more than 10 mg/dl.

Option B - It is reabsorbed at the nephron

  • PAH is not reabsorbed significantly in the nephron; it is almost completely excreted in the urine.

Option C - Clearance of this substance is equal to the GFR:

  • PAH clearance is greater than the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) because PAH undergoes both filtration and secretion in the renal tubules. Inulin clearance is equal to the GFR.

questions.text: Which condition is indicated by the given histology in a 25-year-old male with a history of high fever, runny nose, watery eyes, progressive fever, red eyes, general lymphadenopathy, and a rash that started on the forehead, then face, and then gradually involved, neck, and legs?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Measles:

  • These symptoms and presentations indicate that the patient has a measles infection.
  • The result of FNAC indicates the presence of Warthin- Finkeldey cells.
  • These multinucleated giant cells have numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions in the lymphoid tissue of patients suffering from measles.

Incorrect Options:

Options B: Rubella

  • The rash begins on the face and spreads centrifugally, and Forcheimer spots are seen on the soft palate and uvula.
  • Warthin Finkeldey cells are not a feature

 Option C: Rabies

  • As there is no history of contact/bite from rabies causing animals, this option is ruled out.

Option D:Mumps 

  • It is characterized by acute onset unilateral or bilateral parotid swelling along with fever and do not exhibit Warthin Finkeldey cells.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with complaints of sudden-onset swelling, especially in his lower extremities.On further inquiry, he mentions having consumed a meal  that included fried snacks prepared using mustard oil. Which of the following must have caused this?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C – Sanguinarine:

  • The scenario suggests the diagnosis of epidemic dropsy
  • Caused due to contamination of mustard oil with Argemone oil.
  • A toxin called Sanguinarine is present in Argemone oil.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Aﬂatoxin:

  • Aﬂatoxin causes aflatoxicosis Caused due to groundnuts, maize, jowar getting infested with storage fungus.
  • As the scenario suggests epidemic dropsy, this answer is incorrect

Option B - Pyrrolizidine:

  • Toxin causing Endemic Ascitesis is pyrrolizidine
  • As the scenario suggests epidemic dropsy, this answer is incorrect

Option D - BOAA:

  • BOAA (Beta oxalyl amino alanine) causes lathyrism not epidemic dropsy

questions.text: Which of the following methods of tubectomy is shown in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Parkland Technique:

  • The tubectomy procedure in the image is Parkland Technique
  • Double ligature is used such that tubes are ligated separately

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pomeroy Technique:

Option B - UCHIDA'S Procedure:

Option C - Madlener's Method:

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the method of communication shown in the image?

choices.text: A series of ≥ 4 meetings under an expert
It always has a purpose to impart skills and develop problem-solving skills.

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Didactic method of communication:

  • The image given in the question is a method of communication called a workshop
  • It is a Two-way- Socratic communication not a one-way didactic method. Therefore this option is incorrect

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Socratic method of communication:

  • Workshop is a Socratic method of communication/two-way communication.
  • This is a true statement.

Option C - A series of ≥ 4 meetings under an expert:

  • Workshop includes a series of ≥ 4 meetings under an expert.
  • This is a true statement.

Option D - It always has a purpose to impart skills and develop problem-solving skills:

  • Workshop always has a purpose to impart skills and develop problem-solving skills.

questions.text: A professional weightlifter presents with drooping of the right shoulder, inability to shrug, and lateral winging of the scapula observed when pushing against a wall. The patient is also unable to abduct the right shoulder beyond 90 degrees. The affected muscle responsible for these symptoms is innervated by which motor nerve?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Accessory nerve:

  • The likely diagnosis in this patient is winging of the scapula due to trapezius injury.
  • The trapezius is supplied by the accessory nerve (CN XI).
  • The trapezius is a large muscle of the upper back that extends from the occipital bone to the lower thoracic vertebra and laterally to the spine of the scapula.
  • The main functions of the trapezius are elevation and depression of the shoulders, and rotating the glenoid cavity posteriorly.
  • This muscle along with the serratus anterior is responsible for the abduction of the shoulder beyond 90 degrees.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Lower subscapular nerve: This nerve supplies the teres major muscle. This muscle is primarily responsible for adducting and medially rotating the arm. Hence this option is incorrect.

Option C - Axillary nerve: This nerve supplies the deltoid and the teres minor. The deltoid is responsible for flexion, extension, medial rotation, lateral rotation, and shoulder abduction between 15-90 degrees. The teres minor laterally rotates the arm and holds the humeral head in the glenoid cavity.

Option D - Long thoracic nerve: This nerve supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Patients usually present with medial winging of the scapula unlike in patients with injury to the trapezius/rhomboids.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child is brought to the outpatient department with complaints of bowing of legs and swelling of the wrists and ankles. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of serum calcium, serum phosphate, 25 (OH) Vitamin D3, and calcitriol. Serum alkaline phosphatase and parathyroid hormone levels are elevated. What is the etiology of this child’s presentation?

choices.text: Excessive loss of phosphate in urine

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Nutritional deficiency:

  • The diagnosis in this child is Nutritional rickets and the likely underlying aetiology is a nutritional deficiency of Vitamin D.
  • Since nutritional rickets is primarily due to a deficiency, there are low levels of serum calcium, phosphate, 25 (OH) Vit D3 and 1,25,(OH) Vit D3. Alkaline phosphatase levels are elevated in response to elevated parathyroid hormone levels.

The classical clinical features of Rickets are:

  • Swelling of the wrists and ankles.
  • Lower limb deformities in the form of bow legs/knock knees.
  • Frontal bossing
  • Delayed closure of anterior fontanelle
  • Craniotabes→ Soft skull bones
  • Delayed dentition
  • Beaded appearance of the anterior costochondral junctions —> Rachitic rosary
  • Harrison sulcus → Depression on the chest wall due to the pull of the diaphragm on a weakened chest wall.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Deficiency of 1-alpha-hydroxylase:

  • Deficiency of this enzyme leads to a condition known as Vitamin D-dependent rickets type-1. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of calcium, phosphate, and 1,25-(OH)2D3. Normal levels of 25(OH)D3, and elevated levels of PTH and ALP are also seen.

Option C - End organ resistance to 1,25 - (OH)2D3:

  • Deficiency of this enzyme leads to a condition known as Vitamin D-dependent rickets type-2. Laboratory investigations reveal low levels of calcium, phosphate, and increased levels of 1,25-(OH)2D3. Normal levels of 25(OH)D3, and elevated levels of PTH and ALP are also seen.

Option D - Excess loss of phosphate in urine:

  • Familial hypophosphatemic rickets is an inherited disorder due to low serum phosphate levels. In this disorder, there is excessive loss of phosphate in the urine. Laboratory investigations reveal normal to slightly low levels of calcium, low levels of phosphate, and elevated levels of ALP

questions.text: Which among the following is the recommended dietary allowance for vitamin C in infants ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 30-40 mg/day:

  • The RDA of Vitamin C is 30-40 mg/day in infants and 40-70 mg/day in children >1 year of age.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D:

  • The correct RDA has been mentioned in the explanation above.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with a several-month history of intermittent headaches and episodes of confusion. Neurological examination reveals focal seizures and imaging studies show a well-circumscribed, contrast-enhancing mass in the frontal lobe. The tumor exhibits a "fried egg" appearance with clear cytoplasmic halos on histopathology. What is the expected chromosomal defect in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Co-deletion 1p/19q:

  • The mentioned clinical features, imaging studies, and histological features suggest a diagnosis of oligodendroglioma.
  • Oligodendrogliomas are a type of brain tumor that arises from oligodendrocytes, a type of glial cell in the central nervous system. These tumors are characterized by a specific chromosomal abnormality known as co-deletion of 1p/19q.
  • This means that both the short arm of chromosome 1 (1p) and the long arm of chromosome 19 (19q) are deleted in the tumor cells.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Ch22q12 deletion: Deletion on chromosome 22q12 is not a characteristic chromosomal defect associated with oligodendrogliomas. Chromosome 22q12 abnormalities are more commonly associated with meningiomas.

Option B - Ch3p deletion: Deletion on the short arm of chromosome 3 (3p) is not a typical chromosomal defect in oligodendrogliomas. However, alterations on chromosome 3 are associated with other types of brain tumors, such as hemangioblastomas as in Von Hippel-Lindau disease.

Option D - Deletion 19q: While deletions on the long arm of chromosome 19 (19q) are associated with oligodendrogliomas, the characteristic feature in these tumors is the co-deletion of 1p/19q. Isolated deletion of 19q is more specific to oligoastrocytoma and astrocytoma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman at 34 weeks gestation presents to the antenatal clinic with a complaint of headache for the last 2 days. Her BP is 190/110 mmHg. The urine dipstick test is positive for protein (+2). She is admitted for evaluation and management. Which of the following method involves MgSo4 administration in both IV and IM form in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pritchard regimen:

  • Pritchard regimen: IV +IM is the Method of choice for giving Mgso4 in eclampsia
  • Dose: 14 grams of MgSO - Loading dose 4
    • 4 grams in IV dilution
    • 10 grams of MgSO IM + 1 ml lidocaine (to reduce pain on injection site) 4
      • 5 grams - IM in one buttock
      • 5 grams - IM in another buttock
    • +2 grams of MgSO IV if there is no control in convulsions

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Zuspan regimen:

Zuspan regimen is not the method of choice although it can be given.

  • Loading Dose:
    • 4 grams of MgSO4: Administered as a slow IV bolus over 5-10 minutes.
  • Maintenance Dose:
    • 2 grams per hour of MgSO4: Administered as a continuous IV infusion.

Option C - Ochsner–Sherren regimen:

  • Ochsner–Sherren regimen is for appendicitis not eclampsia
  • Pritchard regimen is the method of choice for giving Mgso4 in eclampsia

Option D - IV Magnesium sulfate:

  • IV Magnesium sulphate is the drug of choice but the question is asking the method of choice for eclampsia

questions.text: A 40-year-old male works as a textile factory worker and presents with complaints of Shortness of breath Chest tightness, and Cough, especially on workdays.Which of the following is he suffering from?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Byssinosis:

  • Byssinosis is an occupational lung disease caused by the inhalation of cotton, flax, or hemp dust. Symptoms include wheezing, chest tightness, and cough, typically occurring on workdays.
  • The presented scenario aligns with the clinical features of byssinosis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Bagassosis: Bagassosis is caused by the inhalation of moldy sugar cane dust. Symptoms may include cough, fever, and chest tightness. It is not the correct diagnosis in this scenario.

Option C - Baritosis: Baritosis results from inhalation of barium sulfate dust. It is typically asymptomatic or causes mild respiratory irritation. The scenario does not match the clinical features of baritosis.

Option D - Caplan's Syndrome: Caplan's Syndrome is characterized by rheumatoid nodules in the lungs, occurring in individuals with rheumatoid arthritis who are exposed to coal dust. It is not the correct diagnosis for the presented scenario.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female schizophrenia patient on haloperidol presents with symptoms of fever, sweating, disorientation, and rigidity for one day. On investigation, CPK levels are increased with leukocytosis and elevated blood pressure. Which of the following is the likely condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Neuroleptic malignant syndrome:

  • The patient's presentation with fever, sweating, disorientation, rigidity, increased blood pressure, elevated CPK levels, and leukocytosis is suggestive of Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS)
  • NMS is a potentially life-threatening condition associated with the use of antipsychotic medications, particularly typical antipsychotics such as haloperidol.
  • Symptoms include hyperthermia (fever), autonomic dysregulation (sweating, increased blood pressure), altered mental status (disorientation), and generalized muscle rigidity.
  • Increased levels of creatine phosphokinase (CPK) are indicative of muscle breakdown, and leukocytosis may be present.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Acute Dystonia:

  • Acute dystonia involves sudden-onset, sustained muscle contractions or spasms, often affecting the head and neck.
  • While acute dystonia is a known extrapyramidal side effect of antipsychotic medications, it does not typically present with fever, disorientation, or systemic symptoms as seen in this case.

Option C - Viral Encephalitis:

  • Viral encephalitis is characterized by inflammation of the brain and is not associated with the use of antipsychotic medications.
  • The symptoms of viral encephalitis may include headache, altered consciousness, seizures, and focal neurological signs.

Option D - Tardive Dyskinesia:

  • Tardive dyskinesia is a delayed-onset side effect of antipsychotic medications, characterized by involuntary and repetitive movements, often involving the face and tongue.
  • Tardive dyskinesia is not associated with fever, rigidity, or altered mental status.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death in a patient with high-grade fever, cough, neck swelling, a thick grey membrane covering the throat and tonsils, and the given findings on Albert staining?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Myocarditis:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of diphtheria, and the presence of small, slender, non-motile, unencapsulated rods with metachromatic granules suggest volutin granules seen in the patients suffering from diphtheria.
  • Myocarditis is the most common complication of diphtheria and the leading cause of death in diphtheria cases, whose incidence is 10- 25%.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B and D are not the most common cause of death in patients with Diphtheria.

questions.text: In a workplace accident, a 45-year-old man experienced compression of his right forearm under a heavy machine for over 3 hours. He presents with intense pain in his right forearm and hand, accompanied by sensations of numbness and weakness. The affected limb appears cool, pale, and swollen upon physical examination. Which of the following statements about the given condition is inaccurate?

choices.text: Flexor digitorum profundus is most commonly affected
Most common triggering factor in children is a supracondylar fracture
Max page's operation is done in type I cases

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Max page's operation is done in type I cases:

  • The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture. In Type I, the Turn buckle's splint (Volkmann's splinting) is done, not Max Page's operation. Max Page's operation (also known as fasciotomy) is typically performed in Type II Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, B, and D are correct regarding VIC.

questions.text: A patient presented with limited abduction of the right eye. Which of the following muscles acts as a contralateral synergist for the affected muscle in dextroversion?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Left MR:

  • Contralateral synergists, aka the yoke muscles, are contralaterally paired extraocular muscles that work synergistically to direct the gaze in a given direction.
  • The dextroversion requires abduction of the right eye facilitated by the right lateral rectus and adduction of the left eye facilitated by the left medial rectus muscle, which are contralateral synergist to each other.

Incorrect Options:

Option A, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option B for an explanation.

questions.text: A newborn’s intestines are protruding from an abdominal wall defect in the space lateral to the umbilicus and not covered by any lining. Which of the following is not a correct statement regarding this neonate’s diagnosis?

choices.text: The intestine comes out of the amnion
This condition is usually associated with multiple congenital anomalies

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - This condition is usually associated with multiple congenital anomalies:

  • The likely diagnosis in this child is Gastroschisis, and it is usually not associated with other congenital anomalies.
  • Gastroschisis is a condition characterized by intestinal herniation at an abdominal weak spot. This defect is usually lateral to the umbilicus and is not covered by any lining. On the contrary, the Omphalocele is usually midline, and the intestines herniate through the umbilicus hence, they are covered by a lining.
  • Unlike gastroschisis, Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies, such as neural tube defects, cardiovascular malformations, and chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Options A, B and D are correct statements.

questions.text: During an abdominal surgery, a surgeon identifies the splenogastric ligament. Which of the following structures is most likely to be found within this ligament?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:

C) Left gastroepiploic artery

Explanation:

The splenogastric ligament, also known as the gastrosplenic ligament, connects the greater curvature of the stomach to the hilum of the spleen. This ligament contains the short gastric arteries and the left gastroepiploic artery, which are branches of the splenic artery. The left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach, providing blood supply to both the stomach and the spleen.

Incorrect Answers:

  1. Tail of the pancreas (A):

    • Explanation: The tail of the pancreas is located near the spleen and is associated with the splenorenal ligament, not the splenogastric ligament.
    • Why Incorrect: It is not found within the splenogastric ligament.

  2. Splenic artery (B):

    • Explanation: The splenic artery runs along the superior border of the pancreas and enters the hilum of the spleen within the splenorenal ligament.
    • Why Incorrect: It is not located within the splenogastric ligament but rather the splenorenal ligament.

  3. Common bile duct (D):

    • Explanation: The common bile duct is part of the biliary system, located near the liver and duodenum.
    • Why Incorrect: It has no anatomical relation to the splenogastric ligament.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding ryanodine receptors( RyR)?

choices.text: RyR1 is found primarily in smooth muscle cells
RyR2 is found primarily in myocardium cells
RyR3 is found primarily in epithelial cells
Release of Sarcoplasmic Calcium through Ryanodine Receptors is a positive feedback control system

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - RyR1 is found primarily in smooth muscle cells:

  • RyR1 is found primarily in skeletal muscles not in smooth muscle cells

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C and D are true statements

questions.text: Which parameter is common to both MELD and Child-Pugh scores?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - International Normalized Ratio:

  • The International Normalized Ratio(INR) is a common parameter to both MELD and Child-Pugh scores.

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D are included in the Child-Pugh score only.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department with symptoms of increased intracranial pressure following a traumatic brain injury. The attending physician considers administering mannitol to reduce the intracranial pressure. However, the patient's medical history reveals that he has been experiencing oliguria and signs of acute kidney injury.

Which of the following is a contraindication for the use of mannitol in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Acute kidney injury:

  • Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to reduce intracranial pressure and treat cerebral edema by drawing fluid out of the brain tissue and into the bloodstream, which is then excreted by the kidneys.
  • However, in patients with acute kidney injury, mannitol is contraindicated because impaired renal function can prevent its excretion, leading to potential fluid overload and exacerbation of renal failure.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Increased intracranial pressure: This is an indication for mannitol, not a contraindication. Mannitol is commonly used to treat elevated intracranial pressure.

Option C - Hypovolemia: While hypovolemia is a concern with any diuretic, it is not the primary contraindication in the context of this question. However, caution is warranted in hypovolemic patients as mannitol can exacerbate fluid loss.

Option D - Hypertension: Hypertension is not a contraindication for mannitol. Mannitol's primary role in this context is to reduce intracranial pressure, and it does not directly affect blood pressure.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic with a complaint of heavy menstrual bleeding. Her pelvic examination is unremarkable. Pathology evaluation reveals simple endometrial hyperplasia with atypia. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Hysterectomy:

  • The incidence of endometrial cancers in a case of simple hyperplasia with atypia is 8 %.
  • In endometrial hyperplasia with atypia: Total hysterectomy is the best management option.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Medroxyprogesterone acetate:

  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate in high doses can be used in women without atypia for uterine conservation.

Option C - Levonorgesterel IUCD:

  • Levonorgestrel Intrauterine contraceptive device (LNG-IUCD) is also a progesterone-releasing IUCD with the same function as oral progesterone and may be given in women with hyperplasia without atypia.

Option D - Radiotherapy:

  • Radiotherapy is not a treatment used for endometrial carcinoma.

questions.text: What intracellular action is triggered by a fragment of the cholera toxin responsible for rice water stools and severe dehydration?

choices.text: Blocking sodium channels in the intestinal epithelium.
Blocking the binding of GM¹ ganglioside
Promotes the binding of GM1 ganglioside

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Activating adenylate cyclase:

  • Cholera toxin stimulates adenylate cyclase, leading to increased levels of intracellular cyclic AMP (cAMP). This, in turn, activates the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) chloride channel and inhibits sodium absorption, resulting in characteristic rice water stools and dehydration.

Incorrect Options:

Options A: Activation of adenylate cyclase inhibits sodium absorption.

Options B and C are incorrect, as a mechanism of action is the activation of adenylate cyclase.

questions.text: An 18-year-old female patient presents with complaints of blurry vision and frequent changes in her prescription glasses. Upon examination, you notice a characteristic finding as shown in the image in her left eye. Which Purkinje image will be used to measure the curvature of this cornea to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A – Image I:

  • The frequent changes of prescribed glasses in young adults and characteristic finding seen in the given image is of, i.e., Munson’s sign (V-shaped deformity of the lower lid on down gaze) are suggestive of keratoconus. The Purkinje image used in keratometry to measure anterior corneal curvature is Image I.
  • The anterior surface of the cornea is a convex mirror, so the size of the image formed by the anterior surface varies with its curvature. Therefore, the size of the image formed by the anterior surface of the cornea (First Purkinje image) and the radius of the curvature of the cornea can be calculated.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C, and D are incorrect. Refer to Option A for an explanation.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by Parvovirus B19 infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - 5th disease:

  • Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent of Fifth disease, also known as erythema infectiosum. This condition is characterized by a "slapped cheek" appearance, where the child's cheeks become very red. Additionally, a lacy, reticular rash often appears on the arms, legs, and trunk.

Incorrect Options:

Option A:1st disease is measles caused by rubeola virus

Option B:3rd disease is scarlet fever caused by Group A Streptococcus

Option C :4th disease is german measles also known as rubella is caused by rubella virus

questions.text: The given histology slide shows a specific type of gland secretion. This secretion is found in which of the following glands?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Salivary glands:

  • The given slide is representing Merocrine Glands
  • Also called eccrine glands
  • Secretions are released without the loss of cell membrane.
  • Example: Salivary glands

 

Incorrect Options:

  • Option A, B and D are incorrect as they are apocrine glands.

questions.text: Which laboratory test is most appropriate for monitoring the anticoagulant effect of warfarin, and what is the primary mechanism of action of this drug?

choices.text: Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT); Direct thrombin inhibition
International normalized ratio (INR); Vitamin K antagonism

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - International normalized ratio (INR); Vitamin K antagonism:

  • Warfarin exerts its anticoagulant effect by inhibiting vitamin K epoxide reductase, which reduces the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (II, VII, IX, and X).
  • The effectiveness and safety of warfarin are monitored using the INR, which standardizes the prothrombin time (PT) to account for variations in laboratory reagents and provides a consistent measure of anticoagulation.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT); Direct thrombin inhibition: aPTT is used to monitor heparin therapy, not warfarin. Direct thrombin inhibitors, such as dabigatran, directly inhibit thrombin but do not require aPTT for routine monitoring.

Option B - Platelet count; Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibition: Platelet count is not used to monitor warfarin. Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa inhibitors (e.g., abciximab) prevent platelet aggregation but are not monitored using platelet count.

Option D - Anti-Xa assay; Factor Xa inhibition: Anti-Xa assays are used to monitor low molecular weight heparins (e.g., enoxaparin) and direct oral anticoagulants that inhibit Factor Xa (e.g., rivaroxaban). These are not relevant to warfarin's mechanism or monitoring.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about intraperitoneal bladder rupture is TRUE?

choices.text: It is more common in females than in males
CT cystography is the investigation of choice for diagnosis
Management usually involves only peritoneal lavage without bladder repair

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - CT cystography is the investigation of choice for diagnosis:

  • CT cystography is indeed the preferred diagnostic method for identifying intraperitoneal bladder rupture.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - It is more common in females than in males: Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is more common in males.

Option C - Ultrasound typically shows a "sunburst" appearance: On cystography, a "sunburst" appearance is noted, while ultrasound typically shows a "bladder in bladder" appearance.

Option D - Management usually involves only peritoneal lavage without bladder repair: Management typically includes exploratory laparotomy, peritoneal lavage, repair of the defect, and insertion of a suprapubic catheter or Foley's catheter.

questions.text: A 51 year old male patient experiences drooping eyelids that worsen as the day progresses, along with increased fatigue towards the end of the day which improves with rest. Additionally, the patient notices a significant decrease in drooping when placing an ice pack over their eyes. Which of the following is not true regarding the diagnosis?

choices.text: Antibody against P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel
Anti-Muscle-specific kinase antibody leads to a poor response to treatment with pyridostigmine
Females are more commonly affected than males

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Antibody against P/Q voltage-gated calcium channel:

  • The above-given scenario with main complaints of ptosis and positive ice pack test is suggestive of myasthenia gravis
  • However, the statement is true regarding the diagnosis of Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) not myasthenia gravis.
  • LEMS is characterized by the presence of antibodies against the P/Q voltage-gated calcium channels at the neuromuscular junction, leading to impaired acetylcholine release and muscle weakness.

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are true regarding myasthenia gravis

  • Females are more commonly affected than males
  • Anti-Muscle-specific kinase antibody leads to a poor response to treatment with pyridostigmine
  • Flattening of the Postsynaptic folds

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents with fatigue, weight gain, and cold intolerance. On examination, she has a diffuse, non-tender goiter. Laboratory tests reveal an elevated thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level and decreased free thyroxine (FT4) level. Antithyroglobulin antibodies are also detected. The histology of the thyroid parenchyma is shown below. This patient is at increased risk of developing which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Papillary Carcinoma Thyroid:

  • The given symptoms and lab findings, along with the histology showing thyroid parenchyma with dense lymphocytic infiltration, are indicative of Hashimoto’s Thyroiditis.
  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer and is often associated with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis, which includes Hashimoto's thyroiditis. Individuals with Hashimoto's thyroiditis papillary carcinoma compared to the general population.

 

Incorrect Options:
